revision.text:
[[Image:Jamesfreemanclarke.jpg|thumb|right|200px|James Freeman Clarke.]] '''James Freeman Clarke''' (April 4, 1810 – June 8, 1888) was an American theologian and author.
==Biography== Born in [[Hanover, New Hampshire]], James Freeman Clarke attended the [[Boston Latin School]], graduated from [[Harvard College]] in 1829, and [[Harvard Divinity School]] in 1833. Ordained into the [[Unitarianism|Unitarian]] church he first became an active minister at [[Louisville, Kentucky]], then a [[slave state]], and soon threw himself into the national movement for the [[Abolitionism in the United States|abolition of slavery]]. His mild theology was unusual for the conservative town and, reportedly, several women walked out of his first sermon. As he wrote to his friend [[Margaret Fuller]], "I am a broken-winged hawk, seeking to fly at the sun, but fluttering in the dust."<ref>Marshall, Megan. ''Margaret Fuller: A New American Life''. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, 2013: 77. {{ISBN|978-0-547195605}}</ref>
In 1839 he returned to Boston where he and his friends established (1841) the [[Church of the Disciples]] which brought together a body of people to apply the [[Christianity|Christian religion]] to social problems of the day. One of the features that distinguished his church was Clarke's belief that ordination could make no distinction between him and them. They also were called to be ministers of the highest religious life. Of this church he was the minister from 1841 until 1850 and again from 1854 until his death. He was also secretary of the Unitarian Association and, in 1867-1871, professor of natural religion and Christian doctrine at Harvard.
Clarke contributed essays to ''The Christian Examiner'', ''The Christian Inquirer'', ''The Christian Register'', ''[[The Dial]]'', ''[[Harper's]]'', ''The Index'', and ''[[Atlantic Monthly]]''. In addition to sermons, speeches, hymnals, and liturgies, he published 28 books and over 120 pamphlets during his lifetime. Clarke edited the ''Western Messenger'', a magazine intended to carry to readers in the [[Mississippi Valley]] simple statements of liberal religion and what were then the most radical appeals to national duty and the abolition of slavery. Copies of this magazine are now valued by collectors for containing the earliest printed poems of [[Ralph Waldo Emerson]], a personal friend and a distant cousin.<ref>Richardson, Jr., Robert D. ''Emerson: The Mind on Fire''. Berkeley & Los Angeles, CA: The University of California Press, 1995: p.175. {{ISBN|0-520-08808-5}}</ref> Clarke became a member of the [[Transcendental Club]] alongside Emerson and several others.<ref>Gura, Philip F. ''American Transcendentalism: A History''. New York: Hill and Wang, 2007: 7–8. {{ISBN|0-8090-3477-8}}</ref> Many of Clarke's earlier published writings were addressed to the immediate need of establishing a larger theory of religion than that espoused by people who were still under the influence of [[Calvinism]].
For the ''Western Messenger'', Clarke requested written contributions from Margaret Fuller. Clarke published Fuller's first literary review—criticisms of recent biographies on [[George Crabbe]] and [[Hannah More]].<ref>Von Mehren, Joan. ''Minerva and the Muse: A Life of Margaret Fuller''. Amherst: [[University of Massachusetts Press]], 1994: 64–66. {{ISBN|1-55849-015-9}}</ref> She later became the first full-time book reviewer in journalism working for [[Horace Greeley|Horace Greeley's]] ''[[New York Tribune]]''.<ref>Callow, Philip. ''From Noon to Starry Night: A Life of Walt Whitman''. Chicago: Ivan R. Dee, 1992: 110. {{ISBN|0-929587-95-2}}</ref> After Fuller's death in 1850, Clarke worked with [[William Henry Channing]] and Emerson as editors of ''The Memoirs of Margaret Fuller Ossoli'', published in February 1852.<ref name=VonMehren343>Von Mehren, Joan. ''Minerva and the Muse: A Life of Margaret Fuller''. Amherst: [[University of Massachusetts Press]], 1994: 343. {{ISBN|1-55849-015-9}}</ref> The trio censored or reworded many of Fuller's letters;<ref>Blanchard, Paula. ''Margaret Fuller: From Transcendentalism to Revolution''. Reading, Massachusetts: Addison-Wesley Publishing Company, 1987: 339. {{ISBN|0-201-10458-X}}</ref> they believed the public interest in Fuller would be temporary and that she would not survive as a historical figure.<ref>Von Mehren, Joan. ''Minerva and the Muse: A Life of Margaret Fuller''. Amherst: [[University of Massachusetts Press]], 1994: 342. {{ISBN|1-55849-015-9}}</ref> Nevertheless, for a time, the book was the best-selling biography of the decade and went through thirteen editions before the end of the century.<ref name=VonMehren343/>
In 1855, Clarke purchased the former site of [[Brook Farm]], intending to start a new [[Utopia]]n community there. This never came to pass, instead the land was offered to President [[Abraham Lincoln]] during the [[American Civil War]]; the Second Massachusetts Regiment used it for training and named it "Camp Andrew".<ref>Felton, R. Todd. ''A Journey into the Transcendentalists' New England''. Berkeley, California: Roaring Forties Press, 2006: 129. {{ISBN|0-9766706-4-X}}</ref> In November 1861, Clarke was in Washington, D.C. with [[Samuel Gridley Howe]] and [[Julia Ward Howe]]. After hearing the song "[[John Brown's Body]]", he suggested that Mrs. Howe write new lyrics; the result was "[[The Battle Hymn of the Republic]]".<ref>Williams, Gary. ''Hungry Heart: The Literary Emergence of Julia Ward Howe''. Amherst: [[University of Massachusetts Press]], 1999: 208. {{ISBN|1-55849-157-0}}</ref>
Clarke was an advocate of human rights. Being a Boston Latin School alumnus, he served on a committee of the Massachusetts Society for the University Education of Women which was greatly instrumental in establishing Girls' Latin School in 1878. Tempered and moderate in his views of life, he was a reformer and a conciliator and never carried a pistol as fellow preacher [[Theodore Parker]] did. He published few verses, but is regarded by some as a poet at heart. A diligent scholar, among the books by which he became well known is one called ''Ten Great Religions'' (2 vols, 1871–1883).
James Freeman Clarke was one of the very first Americans to explore and write about Eastern religions.
A portrait of Clarke painted by [[Edwin Tryon Billings|E.T. Billings]] hangs in the [[Boston Public Library, McKim Building|Boston Public Library]].<ref>http://www.bpl.org/general/trustees/clarke.htm Retrieved 2010-10-02</ref>
==Selected writings== *"Common Sense in Religion" (1874) *''Essentials and Non-Essentials in Religion: Six Lectures Delivered in the Music Hall, Boston'' (1878) *"Self-Culture: Physical, Intellectual, Moral, and Spiritual" (1880) *"Memorial and Biographical Sketches" (1880) *''Every-Day Religion'' (1886) *''Sermons on the Lord's Prayer'' (1888) *"Autobiography, Diary and Correspondence" (1891)
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{commons category}} {{Wikisource author}} {{wikiquote}} * [https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1888/06/18/112634098.pdf New York Times Obituary] * {{Gutenberg author |id=Clarke,+James+Freeman | name=James Freeman Clarke}} ** [http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/14674 ''Ten Great Religions''] * {{Internet Archive author |sname=James Freeman Clarke |sopt=t}} * {{Librivox author |id=1498}} *[http://uudb.org/articles//jamesfreemanclarke.html James Freeman Clarke, Dictionary of Unitarian & Universalist Biography] ;Papers * [http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:DIV.LIB:div00062 James Freeman Clarke Papers], at Andover-Harvard Theological Library at Harvard Divinity School * The [http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:DIV.LIB:div00447 James Freeman Clarke Papers] relating to lectures and the Church of the Disciples, at Andover-Harvard Theological Library at Harvard Divinity School * [http://id.lib.harvard.edu/aleph/000602406/catalog James Freeman Clarke Correspondence] at [[Houghton Library]], Harvard University * [http://id.lib.harvard.edu/aleph/009502771/catalog James Freeman Clarke Letters to] [[Margaret Fuller]], at Houghton Library, Harvard University
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Clarke, James Freeman}} [[Category:Harvard Divinity School alumni]] [[Category:19th-century American writers]] [[Category:American religious leaders]] [[Category:American Unitarians]] [[Category:1810 births]] [[Category:1888 deaths]] [[Category:Members of the Transcendental Club]] [[Category:American abolitionists]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]]

{{onesource|date=February 2017}} Blessed '''James of Padua''' (died 1321) was a 14th-century [[Franciscan]] missionary. He was beheaded alongside [[Thomas of Tolentino]], [[Peter of Siena (died 1321)|Peter of Siena]] and [[Demetrius of Tiflis]] at [[Thane]] by Muslims en route to evangelizing [[Sri Lanka]] and [[China]]. They were [[beatification|beatified]] by [[pope Leo XIII]] in [[1894]] as the Four{{nbsp}}Martyrs{{nbsp}}of{{nbsp}}Thane,<ref name=vat>{{citation |contribution=9 Aprile: S. Tommaso di Tolentino |url=http://www.vatican.va/roman_curia/pontifical_academies/cult-martyrum/martiri/009.html |title=Martirologio |location=Vatican City |publisher=Holy See |accessdate=9 November 2016 }}. {{it icon}}</ref> with their memorial on 9 April.
==References== <references/>
==Sources== *http://catholicsaints.info/blessed-james-of-padua/
[[Category:Franciscan beatified people]] [[Category:Italian beatified people]] [[Category:14th-century people]] [[Category:People from Padua]] [[Category:1321 deaths]]
{{reli-bio-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2015}} {{Use British English|date=December 2015}} {{Multiple issues | {{refimprove|date=July 2012}} {{advert|date=July 2012}} }}
[[File:John and Caitlin Matthews, Oxford, Authors.jpg|thumb|alt= John and Caitlin Matthews|John and Caitlin Matthews]] '''John Matthews''' (born 1948) and '''Caitlín Matthews''' (born 1952) are English writers. Together, they have written over 150 books, translated into more than thirty languages, including [[Tarot]] packs, a card-based storytelling system, screenplays, songs and other works.
Beginning to work together in London in the 1970s,<ref>{{cite book|last=Hutton|first=Ronald|title=Witches, Druids and King Arthur|year=2003|publisher=Hambledon Continuum,|page=244}}</ref> they wrote and published ''The Western Way'' in 1985. This followed the lead of Christine Hartley's ''The Western Mysteries Tradition'' (1968)<ref>{{cite book|last=Matthews|first=Caitlín and John|title=The Western Way: Practical Guide to the Western Mystery Tradition}}</ref> by identifying and promoting a [[Europe]]an mystical tradition to offset the then-current domination of Eastern mysticisms from India and China.<ref>Hutton 2003, pages 245–46.</ref> The book included meditations to enable readers to make contact with their inner worlds.<ref>{{cite book|last=Harvey|first=Graham|title=Listening People, Speaking Earth: Contemporary Paganism|year=1997|publisher=Hurst|page=115}}</ref> Historian [[Ronald Hutton]] considers this an influential work.<ref>Hutton 2003, page 246.</ref> They also edited ''The Encyclopedia of Celtic Wisdom'' (2000), devised the Storyworld series (2009ff) and, most recently, created ''The Steampunk Tarot: Gods of the Machine'' (2012).
They studied with two of the leading esotericists of the time, Gareth Knight and Dolorous Ashcroft-Nowicki,<ref>{{cite book|last=Knight pp|first=Gareth|title=I Called it Magic|year=2011|publisher=Skylight Press|pages=36–38, 47–49, 135–40}}</ref> and from 1988 to 1992 they served as joint-presiders of the [[Order of Bards, Ovates and Druids]].<ref>{{cite web|title=OBOD Past Presidents:|url=http://www.druidry.org/about-us/past-presiders-order}}</ref> Since 1989 they have run the Fellowship of Isis Lyceum, Domus Sophiae Terrae et Sancte Gradalis in Oxford, and are both members of the Archpriesthood Union as custodians of the legacy of the Fellowship of Isis.<ref>{{cite web|title=Portal of Isis|url=http://www.portalofisis.info/subpage5.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120424161756/http://www.portalofisis.info/subpage5.html|archivedate=24 April 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
They are active on the [[New Age]] workshop circuit, teaching their versions of the Celtic mysteries, [[Neo-shamanism]], the Goddess and King Arthur.<ref>Hutton 2003, page 246.</ref> They were jointly listed 86th in the Watkins list of the 100 most spiritually influential living people worldwide for 2011.<ref>{{Cite journal|title =100 most spiritually influential living people | journal =The Watkins Review| issue =26 | year =2011| pages=3–7 | publisher=Watkins Books |url =http://www.lifewithoutacentre.com/wp-content/uploads/Spiritual100List.pdf |accessdate=8 May 2015}}</ref> They live in [[Oxford]], [[united kingdom|UK]].
== John Matthews == [[File:John Matthews, Author, 086.jpg|upright|thumb|alt= John Matthews|John Matthews]] '''John Matthews''' (born 1948) has been involved in study of the mysteries of Britain including the [[Arthurian Legends]] and the [[Grail Myth]], for almost fifty years.<ref>{{cite book |title=The Book of English Magic |author=Philip Carr-Gomm |author2=Richard Heygate |year=2009 |publisher=John Murray |isbn=978-1-44-473454-6 |page=150}}</ref> He has published over ninety books on myth, the Arthurian Legends and Grail studies, including ''The Grail: Quest for the Eternal'' (1981), and most recently ''The Camelot Oracle'' (2012, with Will Worthington). He has also published short stories, a volume of poetry, and several children's books, most notably ''Pirates'' (2006) which was on the [[New York Times best-seller list]] for twenty-two weeks.<ref>{{cite book|last=Matthews|first=John|title=Pirates|year=2006|publisher=Carlton/Harper Collins|url=http://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/pirates-john-matthews/1100234992}}</ref> His book ''Arthur of Albion'' (2009) won multiple awards, including a Gold Medal from NAPPA, a gold [[Moonbeams award]] <ref>{{cite web|title=Moonbeam Award|url=http://www.moonbeamawards.com/}}</ref> and a BIB Golden Apple Award.
He has taught throughout [[Europe]] and the [[United States]]<ref>Carr-Gomm and Heygate 2009, page 150.</ref> and has acted as advisor for a number of media projects including the Jerry Bruckheimer film "[[King Arthur (2004 film)|King Arthur]]" (2004).<ref>{{cite web|title=The Digital Fix|url=http://film.thedigitalfix.com/content/id/13308/interview-with-king-arthur-historians.html}}</ref> He has appeared on the [[History Channel]] and [[Discovery Channel]] programmes on Arthur and the Holy Grail, and shared a [[BAFTA award]] for his work on the educational DVD made to accompany "King Arthur".<ref>{{cite web|title=BAFTA|url=http://www.bafta.org/awards-database.html?sq=King+Arthur}}</ref> He has served as a guest editor for the international journal ''[[Arthuriana]]'', on whose editorial board he also sits.<ref>{{cite web|title=Arthuriana Journale|url=http://www.arthuriana.org/arthurwel.htm}}</ref> In 2009 he set up the production company Mythwood Films with Wil Kinghan, and a full-length feature, "The Mermaids", is forthcoming.
== Caitlín Matthews == [[File:Caitlin Matthews, Author.jpg|upright|thumb|alt= Caitlín Matthews|Caitlín Matthews]] '''Caitlín Matthews''' (born 1952) was born in [[Portsmouth]], [[England]], of British and [[Ireland|Irish]] parents, and from an early age was aware of a spiritual dimension to life.<ref>Hutton 2003, page 244.</ref> She was briefly acquainted with the influential modern Druid [[Ross Nichols]], and trained with [[Dolores Ashcroft-Nowicki]] of the [[Servants of the Light]] (1978–1982).<ref>{{cite web|title=Counter Currents|url=http://www.counter-currents.com/2011/12/of-winter-kings-and-snap-dragons/}}</ref> She was initiated into the [[Fellowship of Isis]] in 1977 and was subsequently ordained as priestess in 1988.<ref>{{cite web|title=Portal of Isis|url=http://www.portalofisis.info/subpage5.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120424161756/http://www.portalofisis.info/subpage5.html|archivedate=24 April 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> She continues as arch-priestess in the Archpriesthood Union, as one of the custodians of the Fellowship of Isis.<ref>Harvey 1997, page 115.</ref>
Following the publication of ''The Western Way'' she has written over sixty books including several works on the divine feminine, and the worlds of [[early Welsh literature|early Welsh]] and [[early Irish literature|Irish literature]].<ref>Hutton 2003, page 143.</ref> Her work reflects both the older academic sources and the newer Celtic mystical ones, but leaves out, according to Hutton, "the scholarly publications of the 1980s, many of which have radically altered existing views of the sources for our knowledge of the ancient Celts."<ref>Hutton 1991, pages 143–44.</ref>
Matthews has led workshops in Britain and elsewhere, including the [[Temenos Academy]], London; [[Regents College]], Oxford; the [[University of Jyväskylä]] in Finland, the [[University of Lisbon]] in Portugal, and at Studium Generale of the Arnhem Institute for the Arts in Netherlands.<ref>{{cite book|last=Fons|first=Elders|title=Mythological Europe Revisited: Humanism and the Third Millennium III ed|year=2001|publisher=VUB University Press|location=Brussels}}</ref>
===Criticism=== Ronald Hutton, commenting on Caitlín Matthews' works, states that she "falls below the standards required of a professional historian. She makes no attempt to distinguish between the relative value of sources, so those from the seventh century and from the seventeenth are put together with no sense of context." He also states that she conditions her work to the needs of her audience and that she has incorrectly suggested parallels between Celtic lore and Native American religion.<ref>{{cite book|last=Hutton|first=Ronald|title=The Pagan Religions of the Ancient British Isles: Their Nature and Legacy,|year=1991|publisher=Blackwell|pages=143–44}}</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Jonathan Dayton and Valerie Faris | image = Jonathan Dayton and Valerie Faris on January 26, 2006.jpg | caption = Dayton and Faris on January 26, 2006 | birth_date = {{nowrap|{{Birth date and age|1957|7|7}}}}

{{nowrap|{{Birth date and age|1958|10|20}}}}
[[Los Angeles County, California]], U.S. (Faris) | notable_works = ''[[Little Miss Sunshine]]''
''[[Ruby Sparks]]''
''[[Battle of the Sexes (2017 film)|Battle of the Sexes]]'' | occupation = Film directors, music video directors | children = 3 }} '''Jonathan Dayton''' (born July 7, 1957) and '''Valerie Faris''' (born October 20, 1958) are a team of American film and [[music video director]]s that received critical acclaim for their feature film directorial debut, ''[[Little Miss Sunshine]]'' (2006). Later the married couple went on to direct the romantic comedy-drama ''[[Ruby Sparks]]'' (2012), and the biographical [[sports film|sports drama]] ''[[Battle of the Sexes (2017 film)|Battle of the Sexes]]'' (2017). They are currently slated to direct a new [[Netflix]] comedy series, ''[[Living With Yourself]]'', starring [[Paul Rudd]].{{cite book |last1=Petski |first1=Denise |title=Paul Rudd To Topline Netflix Comedy Series ‘Living With Yourself’ From Timothy Greenberg |date=August 10, 2018 |publisher=Deadline.com |url=https://deadline.com/2018/08/paul-rudd-netflix-comedy-series-living-with-yourself-timothy-greenberg-1202443531/}} ==Life and career== Dayton was born in [[Alameda County, California]] and grew up in [[Grass Valley, California]]. After graduating from [[Ygnacio Valley High School]] in [[Concord, California]], attended the [[UCLA Film School]], studying film and television in the late-1970s; while there, he met Valerie Faris, a dance student and native of [[Los Angeles County, California]], who became his wife and his partner. They have three children together.{{cite web|title=Jonathan Dayton Biography|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0206760/bio|website=IMDB}} Valerie is the daughter of Paula Forbes, a supervising painter, and Jim Faris, a film editor.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/jim-faris-dead-film-editor-father-director-valerie-faris-dies-at-97-944270 |title=Jim Faris Dead: Film Editor, Father of Director Valerie Faris, Dies at 97 |publisher=Hollywood Reporter |date=2016-11-04 |accessdate=2018-07-26}} As a pair, Dayton and Faris have directed and produced music videos, documentaries, commercials and films. They have directed music videos for bands such as [[Oasis (band)|Oasis]], [[Red Hot Chili Peppers]], [[Beastie Boys]], and [[R.E.M. (band)|R.E.M.]]. Their 1996 video for "[[Tonight, Tonight (The Smashing Pumpkins song)|Tonight Tonight]]" by [[The Smashing Pumpkins]] won six [[MTV Video Music Award]]s. Another video of theirs that received significant success was for the 1990 [[Extreme (band)|Extreme]] song "[[More Than Words]]".{{cite web |title=The Lost Projects of Jonathan Dayton and Valerie Faris |url=http://splitsider.com/2012/07/the-lost-projects-of-jonathan-dayton-and-valerie-faris/ |work=Splitsider |first=Bradford |last=Evans |date=July 19, 2012}} They directed a number of sketches for the 1995-1998 [[HBO]] sketch comedy series ''[[Mr. Show]]''. In 1998, they established a production company, "Bob Industries". Through this company the pair directed commercials for companies such as [[Hewlett-Packard|HP]], [[Volkswagen]], [[Sony]], [[Gap (clothing retailer)|GAP]], [[Target Corporation|Target]], [[IKEA]], [[Apple Computer]], and [[ESPN]]. Most famously, the two directed a 1999 commercial for the [[Volkswagen Cabrio]], titled "Milky Way", whose soundtrack consisted entirely of the 1972 [[Nick Drake]] song "[[Pink Moon]]", and which is credited with single-handedly initiating a massive revival of interest in Nick Drake's music.{{cite web |title=Nick Drake's "Pink Moon" is Rising |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/nick-drakes-pink-moon-is-rising-20000411 |work=Rolling Stone |first=Aidin |last=Vaziri |date=April 11, 2000}} They began to be offered feature films to direct at around this time; among projects that they turned down were ''[[The Mod Squad (film)|The Mod Squad]]'' (1999) and ''[[Bad Boys II]]'' (2003). In 2001, they began to work on the film ''[[Little Miss Sunshine]]''; it was released in 2006. The film won the Audience Award at the 2006 Sydney Film festival and an ovation at the 2006 [[Sundance Film Festival]], and was [[List of accolades received by Little Miss Sunshine|nominated]] for an [[Academy Award for Best Picture]]. In 2006, the pair were announced as the directors of a planned screen adaptation of [[Tom Perrotta]]'s novel ''[[The Abstinence Teacher]]'' for [[Warner Independent Pictures]].LaPorte, Nicole, and Pamela McClintock. [http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117955310.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 "'Sunshine' duo in talks for next feature: Dayton, Faris may adapt 'Abstinence Teacher'"], ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', 2006-12-06. Retrieved on 2007-07-07. In 2007 Perrotta wrote a screenplay with input from Dayton and Faris.Schwartz, Missy. [http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20152501,00.html "The Q&A: Tom Perrotta: His Novel Take on Suburban Life"], [[Entertainment Weekly]], 2007-10-15. Retrieved on 2007-10-20. However, by 2012 they had left the project, and it was taken over by director [[Lisa Cholodenko]].{{cite web |title=Exclusive: Lisa Cholodenko Confirms She'll Direct 'The Abstinence Teacher' & Heads Into The 'Wild' With Reese Witherspoon |url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/lisa-cholodenko-confirms-shell-direct-the-abstinence-teacher-heads-into-the-wild-with-reese-witherspoon-20120511 |work=IndieWire > The Playlist |first=Jen |last=Vineyard |date=May 11, 2012}} Their next film was ''[[Ruby Sparks]]'' in 2012. Dayton and Faris then directed ''[[Battle of the Sexes (2017 film)|Battle of the Sexes]]'', about the famous tennis match between [[Billie Jean King]] and [[Bobby Riggs]], with [[Emma Stone]] as King and [[Steve Carell]] as Riggs. The film also stars [[Elisabeth Shue]], [[Alan Cumming]], and [[Sarah Silverman]], and was released in 2017. ==Filmography== ===Directors=== * ''[[Little Miss Sunshine]]'' (2006) * ''[[Ruby Sparks]]''
