Rogers]] |college=[[Montana Grizzlies football|Montana]] |undraftedyear=2010 |pastteams= * [[Chicago Bears]] ({{NFL Year|2010}}–{{NFL Year|2011}})* * [[Minnesota Vikings]] ({{NFL Year|2012}})* * [[Spokane Shock]] ({{AFL Year|2013}})* * [[BC Lions]] ({{CFL Year|2013}})* * [[Spokane Shock]] ({{AFL Year|2014}})* * [[New Mexico Stars]] (2014) * [[Los Angeles Kiss]] ({{AFL Year|2014}}) |highlights= *2009 All-[[Big Sky Conference]] (unanimous) *2009 [[Division I (NCAA)#Football Championship Subdivision|FCS]] [[All-American]]: (1st team-[[American Football Coaches Association|AFCA]], 3rd team-[[Associated Press|AP]] and [[The Sports Network|TSN]]) |statlabel1=Games Played |statvalue1=0 |statlabel2=Games Started |statvalue2=0 |nfl=HOR141723 |cfl=5865 |afl=12735 }}
'''Levi C. Horn''' (born October 2, 1986) is a former [[American football]] [[offensive tackle]]. He began his college football career at [[Oregon Ducks football|Oregon]] before transferring to [[Montana Grizzlies football|Montana]], where he was a unanimous All-[[Big Sky Conference]] player and an [[Division I (NCAA)#Football Championship Subdivision|FCS]] [[All-American]].
==Early life== Horn graduated from [[John R. Rogers High School]] in Spokane, Washington in 2005.<ref name="ref1">{{cite web|accessdate=2011-09-14|date=2007-01-25|url=http://www.spokesman.com/stories/2005/jan/27/horn-headed-for-oregon/|title=Horn Headed for Oregon|work=[[Spokesman-Review]]|author=Grippi, Vince}}</ref> He was a Class 4A first-team all-state [[tight end]] by the [[Associated Press]] and WashingtonPreps.com.<ref name=LHOCBS>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/draft/players/1633484|title=Levi Horn, OT|accessdate=2011-12-15|publisher=[[CBS Sports]]}}</ref>
He [[redshirt (college sports)|redshirted]] at University of Oregon while moving from tight end to offensive tackle.<ref name=LHOCBS/> He left after the 2005 season along with three other players citing a desire for more playing time.<ref name="moretime">{{cite news|accessdate=2011-09-14|date=2006-06-29|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=2504805|title=Citing lack of playing time, four players leave OU|agency=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref> He then transferred to the University of Montana. He was a first team All-Big Sky Conference selection while at Montana.<ref name="1st">{{cite web|accessdate=2011-09-14|date=2010-04-19|url=http://archive.chicagobreakingsports.com/2010/04/linemen-horn-howell-on-bears-draft-radar.html|title=Linemen Horn, Howell on Bears' draft radar|publisher=ChicagoBreakingSports.com|author=Biggs, Brad}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref name="miss">{{cite web|date=2006-09-26|accessdate=2011-09-14|url=http://missoulian.com/sports/college/montana/article_4720f3f2-aa68-11de-930b-001cc4c03286.html|title=Horn of plenty: Levi Horn got past many stumbling blocks to attain success on and off field|work=[[Missoulian]]|author=Neighbor, Fritz}}</ref> He was a unanimous selection to the 2009 All-Big Sky Conference team.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bigskyconf.com/news/2009/11/24/FBALLCONF09.aspx?path=football|title=League Announces 2009 All-Conference Football Team|accessdate=2011-09-15|date=2009-11-24|publisher=[[Big Sky Conference]]|author=Kasper, John}}</ref> He was also an NCAA [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] [[Division I (NCAA)#Football Championship Subdivision|Football Championship Subdivision]] [[All-American]] selection: [[American Football Coaches Association]] (first team),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bigskyconf.com/news/2009/12/16/AFCA2009.aspx?path=football|title=Five Named to AFCA Squad|accessdate=2011-09-15|date=2009-12-16|publisher=[[Big Sky Conference]]|author=Kasper, John}}</ref> [[Associated Press]] (third team),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bigskyconf.com/news/2009/12/16/APallamerica121609.aspx?path=football|title=Six Earn First Team AP Honors|accessdate=2011-09-15|date=2009-12-16|publisher=[[Big Sky Conference]]|author=Kasper, John}}</ref> and [[The Sports Network]] (third team).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bigskyconf.com/news/2009/12/23/FB_1223092311.aspx?path=football|title=Seventeen Named to Sports Network Team|accessdate=2011-09-15|date=2009-12-23|publisher=[[Big Sky Conference]]|author=Kasper, John}}</ref>
==Professional career==
===Chicago Bears=== After going undrafted in the [[2010 NFL Draft]], Horn signed with the [[Chicago Bears]] as an undrafted free agent on April 25, 2010. He was waived on September 4, 2010 and signed to the Bears' practice squad the next day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2010-09-06/sports/ct-spt-0907-bears-oline--20100906_1_johan-asiata-j-marcus-webb-levi-horn|title=Rebuilding offensive line a long process: Bears bank on Tice to develop youngsters over the years, not months|accessdate=2011-09-14|date=2010-09-06|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|author=Biggs, Brad}}</ref> On January 4, 2011 Horn signed a future contract with the [[Chicago Bears|Bears]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2011-01-05/sports/ct-spt-0106-bits-bears-chicago--20110105_1_packers-defensive-coordinator-levi-horn-injury-report|title=Kreutz says Bears gained playoff experience against Packers: Though 7 offensive starters will be making playoff debuts, Packers showed them postseason intensity|accessdate=2011-09-14|date=2011-01-05|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|author=McClure, Vaughn}}</ref> Horn was released on September 3, 2011,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2011-09-03/sports/chi-bears-release-rb-taylor-dt-harrison-20110903_1_mario-addison-levi-horn-cutdown-day|title=Cutdown day: Bears release Clark, Taylor, Harrison|accessdate=2011-09-14|date=2011-09-03|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|author=Biggs, Brad}}</ref> but he was signed to the practice squad the next day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2011-09-04/sports/chi-bears-resign-wr-adams-to-practice-squad-20110904_1_levi-horn-guard-ricky-henry-wide-receiver-kris-adams|title=Bears re-sign Adams, Horn: add Allen to practice squad|accessdate=2011-09-14|date=2011-09-04|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|author=Biggs, Brad}}</ref> On November 18, he was activated from the practice squad when [[Gabe Carimi]] was placed on injured reserve.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.profootballweekly.com/2011/11/20/nfl-transactions-for-november-18-2011|title=NFL transactions for November 18, 2011|accessdate=2011-12-15|date=2011-11-20|work=[[Pro Football Weekly]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120911123007/http://www.profootballweekly.com/2011/11/20/nfl-transactions-for-november-18-2011|archivedate=September 11, 2012|df=}}</ref> The Bears waived Horn on May 14, 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/football/bears/chi-bears-waive-three-to-clear-roster-space-20120514,0,3147503.story|title=Bears waive three to clear roster space|accessdate=2012-05-17|date=2012-05-14|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|author=Biggs, Brad}}</ref>
===Minnesota Vikings=== Horn signed with the [[Minnesota Vikings]] on May 18, 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.1500espn.com/sportswire/Vikings_sign_former_Bears_offensive_tackle_Levi_Horn051812|title=Vikings sign former Bears offensive tackle Levi Horn|accessdate=2012-05-20|date=2012-05-18|author=Zulgad, Judd|publisher=[[KSTP (AM)|KSTP]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120521182527/http://www.1500espn.com/sportswire/Vikings_sign_former_Bears_offensive_tackle_Levi_Horn051812|archivedate=2012-05-21|df=}}</ref> On August 25, 2012, he was released by the Vikings.<ref>{{cite web|last=Craig|first=Mark|title=No surprises as Vikings cut 15 players|url=http://www.startribune.com/sports/vikings/blogs/167435955.html|publisher=Star Tribune|accessdate=25 August 2012}}</ref>
===2013=== Horn signed with the [[Spokane Shock]] of the [[Arena Football League]] on March 14, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arenafootball.com/sports/a-footbl/spec-rel/031513aab.html|title=Shock Add OL Levi Horn|accessdate=2013-03-18|date=2013-03-15|publisher=ArenaFootball.com}}</ref> He signed with the [[BC Lions]] of the [[Canadian Football League]] on March 26, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/sports/football/lions/Lions+release+veteran+Anthony+Reddick/8155932/story.html|title=Lions release veteran DB Anthony Reddick|accessdate=2013-03-27|date=2013-03-26|work=[[The Vancouver Sun]]|author=Beamish, Mike}}</ref>
===2014=== In 2014 Horn played four games for the [[New Mexico Stars]] of the [[Lone Star Football League]] before signing with the expansion [[Los Angeles Kiss]] of the [[Arena League]] in late April.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abqjournal.com/388023/sports/stars-olineman-horn-signs-with-arenas-la-kiss.html|title=Stars O-lineman Horn signs with Arena League’s LA Kiss|accessdate=2014-04-26|date=2014-04-23|work=[[Albuquerque Journal]]}}</ref> The Kiss placed him on recallable reassignment on May 5.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/afl/sports/a-footbl/auto_pdf/2014-15/release/release_20140507aaa_aflgld.pdf|title=Los Angeles Kiss Game Notes – Week 9|accessdate=2014-05-18|date=2014-05-10|publisher=[[Los Angeles Kiss]]}}</ref> Later that month, he returned to the New Mexico Stars.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abqjournal.com/401945/sports/practice-gets-a-little-salty.html|title=New Mexico Stars practice gets a little ‘salty’|accessdate=2014-05-29|date=2014-05-17|work=[[Albuquerque Journal]]|author=Christ, Bob}}</ref>
==Personal life==
Horn is a registered member of the [[Cheyenne people|Cheyenne tribe]] and has been active in the Native American community.<ref>{{cite web|title=Chicago Bears Levi Horn Visits Spokane Tribe of Indians|url=http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2011/07/chicago-bears-levi-horn-visits-spokane-tribe-of-indians/|publisher=[[Indian Country Today]]|date=July 16, 2011|accessdate=2011-09-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.doi.gov/news/mediaadvisories/BIE-Director-Keith-Moore-Chicago-Bears-Levi-Horn-and-Nike-N7-to-Announce-Presidents-Active-Lifestyle-Award-Challenge-Winning-School.cfm|publisher=[[United States Department of the Interior]]|title=BIE Director Keith Moore, Chicago Bears’ Levi Horn and Nike N7 to Announce President’s Active Lifestyle Award Challenge Winning School|date=2011-05-16|accessdate=2011-09-14}}</ref> He is a spokesman for the White House's [[Let's Move!]] campaign.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=US Department of the Interior|title=Echo Hawk Announces the Bureau of Indian Education’s Participation with Levi Horn and Nike in the Presidential Active Lifestyle Award (PALA) Challenge|date=February 9, 2011|url=http://www.bia.gov/idc/groups/public/documents/text/idc013101.pdf|accessdate=2011-09-15|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303075148/http://www.bia.gov/idc/groups/public/documents/text/idc013101.pdf|archivedate=March 3, 2012|df=}}</ref>

'''Luc Bürgin''' (born August 19, 1970 in [[Basel]]) is a Swiss writer, publicist, and journalist. From 1996 to 2002, Bürgin studied German literature, folklore, musicology, media studies and sociology at the [[University of Basel]]. He has served as a journalist for [[Basler Zeitung Medien]] and as editor in chief of [[Baslerstab]]. He is best known for his writings on [[fringe science]] and [[popular science]].
== Der Urzeit-Code == Published in 2007, Bürgin's book ''Der Urzeit-Code'' (The Primeval Code), is a popular science book dealing with a patent granted in 1980 to the chemical company Ciba-Geigy (now [[Novartis]]), which deals with the process of [[electroculture]], which helped to increase the resilience of crops and reduce the use of pesticides on treated crops. The book details reports and interviews that document the effect of the electroculture process which had not been previously explained scientifically. In the book, Bürgin presents electroculture as a more ecologically-friendly alternative to [[genetic engineering]].
== Works == * ''Chinas mysteriöses Höhlenlabyrinth: Die unterirdische Welt von Huangshan.'' Kopp, Rottenburg 2013, {{ISBN|978-3864450587}}. * ''Mystery: Neue Beweise für das Unerklärliche.'' Kopp, Rottenburg 2012, {{ISBN|978-3864450495}}. * ''Lexikon der verbotenen Archäologie: Mysteriöse Relikte von A bis Z.'' Kopp, Rottenburg 2009, {{ISBN|978-3942016148}}. * ''Der Urzeit-Code: Die ökologische Alternative zur umstrittenen Gen-Technologie.'' Herbig, München 2007, {{ISBN|3-7766-2534-1}}. * ''Psst… streng vertraulich: Brisante Enthüllungen, die man Ihnen verheimlichen wollte.'' Kopp, Rottenburg 2006, {{ISBN|3-938516-36-4}}. * ''Das Wunder Mirin Dajo: Der unverletzbare Prophet und seine paranormalen Kräfte.'' Kopp, Rottenburg 2004, {{ISBN|3-930219-74-3}}. * ''Hochtechnologie im Altertum: Flüsternde Steine, magische Spiegel, ewiges Licht.'' Kopp, Rottenburg 2003, {{ISBN|3-930219-67-0}}. * ''Rätsel der Archäologie: Unerwartete Entdeckungen, unerforschte Monumente.'' Herbig, München 2003, {{ISBN|3-7766-2318-7}}. * ''UFOs über der Schweiz: Das Dossier der Luftwaffe.'' Kopp, Rottenburg 1999, {{ISBN|3-930219-27-1}}. * ''Geheimakte Archäologie: Unterdrückte Entdeckungen, verschollene Schätze, bizarre Funde.'' Bettendorf, München 1998, {{ISBN|3-7766-7002-9}}. * ''Irrtümer der Wissenschaft: Verkannte Genies, Erfinderpech und kapitale Fehlurteile.'' Herbig, München 1997, {{ISBN|3-7766-1986-4}}. * ''Mondblitze: Unterdrückte Entdeckungen in Raumfahrt und Wissenschaft.'' Herbig, München 1994, {{ISBN|3-7766-1849-3}}. * ''Götterspuren: Der neue UFO-Report.'' Herbig, München 1993, {{ISBN|3-7766-1806-X}}. * ''Chinas mysteriöses Höhlenlabyrinth: Die unterirdische Welt von Huangshan'', Kopp, Rottenburg 2013, {{ISBN|3864450586}}
== External links == * {{Helveticat}} * {{DNB-Portal|115806474}} * [http://www.parasearch.de/h/h020102/index.htm Autor und Werke] * [http://www.mysteries-magazin.com/ www.mysteries-magazin.com] * [http://www.urzeit-code.com/ www.urzeit-code.com] * [http://www.mirin-dajo.com/ www.mirin-dajo.com]

1. https://web.archive.org/web/20121105104612/http://tatjana.ingold.ch/index.php?id=goetterspuren
2. http://literaturtest.net/text/buch/rezensio/b/buergin.html
3. Commercial Register: Dr. A. Hedri Foundation for Exopsychology and Epipsychology.
4. http://www.easymonitoring.ch/handelsregister/dr-a-hedri-stiftung-fuer-exopsychologie-und-epipsychologie-275592 Easymonitoring AG, 23 June 2003, accessed on 2 February 2014 .

{{For|the crater|Gauricus (crater)}} {{Refimprove|date=June 2011}} [[Image:Gauricus.JPG|thumb|right|Luca Gaurico]]
'''Luca Gaurico''' (in Latin, '''Lucas Gauricus''') (Giffoni March 12, 1475 – March 6, 1558 in [[Rome]]) was an [[Italy|Italian]] astrologer, astronomer, astrological data collector<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Tractatus_astrologicus_de_genethliacorum.html?id=GsN02Vq7QR0C&redir_esc=y|title=Astrological data collection|work=Tractatus Astrologicus}}</ref> and mathematician. He was born to a poor family in the Kingdom of [[Naples]], and studied [[judicial astrology]], a subject he defended in his ''Oratio de Inventoribus et Astrologiae Laudibus'' (1508). Judicial astrology concerned the fate of man (''astrologia judiciaria''; mundane astrology) as influenced by the stars. His most famous work is the ''Tractatus Astrologicus''.
==Career as astrologer== Gaurico's reputation was such that he served as an "astrological consultant" to [[Catherine de' Medici]]. Gaurico had predicted the accession to the [[papacy]] of Catherine's great-uncle Giovanni de Medici (when he was 14 – who later became [[Leo X]]) and predicted Catherine’s uncle Giulio de Medici involvement in important political struggles and numerous descendants. Giulio de Medici later was to become Pope [[Clement VII]], who involved with disputes with both [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor]] and [[Henry VIII of England]].
[[Giovanni II Bentivoglio]], ruler of [[Bologna]], consulted him about his destiny. Displeased with Gaurico’s prophecy, Bentivoglio subjected Gaurico to the torture of [[mancuerda]], the effects of which he suffered for the rest of his life, and exiled the astrologer. When Bologna fell to Pope [[Julius II]], Gaurico returned to general favor.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20061021084129/http://www.santiagobovisio.com/ing/books/book16.htm BOOK XVI: HISTORY OF THE ESOTERIC ORDERS]. Archived from santiagobovisio.com</ref>
Gaurico became famous after predicting the ascension of Alessandro Farnese, a prediction that came true with Farnese's ascension as [[Paul III]]. Gaurico foretold also the sickness and death of this Pontiff, who died on November 20, 1549, the day said to have been indicated by Gaurico. Paul III obviously did not wait for his death in order to verify Gaurico's prediction. Paul III, who encouraged astrologers to come to [[Rome]] and work under his protection, made Gaurico his unofficial astrologer, and he was made a [[Papal Table Companion]], knighted, and appointed bishop of Giffoni ([[Salerno]] province), and thus described as ''Episcopus Geophonensis'', in 1539. Paul III made Gaurico [[bishop of Civitate]] (San Severo), in [[Capitanata]], in southern [[Italy]], in 1545. Four years after the death of Paul III, Gaurico abandoned these duties and settled in Rome.
The ''Tractatus Astrologicus'' contained the natal charts of popes and cardinals, kings and nobles, scholars, musicians and artists. Gaurico systematically examined each natal chart, compared it to the life of the person in question, and in the case of living subjects, predicted the outcome of their lives and careers. Gaurico also attempted to calculate the exact date of [[Jesus|Jesus']] [[crucifixion]], and the number of hours between it and the resurrection. Allegedly, both he and [[Nostradamus]] were responsible for predicting the death of [[Henry II of France]] in a tournament in 1559.
[[File:Henry II of France..jpg|170px|thumb|Henry II of France, whose death both Nostradamus and Gauricus are said to have predicted.]]
Allegedly, [[Catherine de' Medici]] had wished to know Henry's destiny as the Apparent Heir of France. Allegedly, Gaurico replied that the Heir would exert his royal power, which would first marked by a duel, and finally by another duel that would put a stop to his reign and his life. Allegedly, he also explained in detail the kind of wound that would result in the death of Henry II during this duel.
Allegedly, the danger of this duel was considered impossible because of the social condition of the Prince, and Gaurico was not believed. Allegedly, Gaurico insisted on his statements, printed in France in 1552, that is, seven years before the well-known [[joust]] in which Henry II would find his death. He is also said to have sent a letter to the King repeating with full details his prediction and advising him to avoid any single combat in closed field, especially around the time when he had reached 41 years of age, since a wound on his head, at this age, could produce his blindness or his death. Allegedly, the letter did not deter Henry.
On July 1, 1559, during a match to celebrate the [[Peace of Cateau Cambrésis|Peace Treaty of Cateau-Cambrésis]] with his longtime enemies, the [[Habsburg]]s of Austria and to celebrate the marriage of his daughter [[Elizabeth of Valois]] to King [[Philip II of Spain]], during the final joust, King Henry's eye was pierced by a sliver that penetrated the brain, from the shattered lance of [[Gabriel Montgomery]], captain of the King's [[Scotland|Scottish]] Guard. He suffered terribly, and, despite the efforts of royal surgeon [[Ambroise Paré]], died on July 10, 1559 and was buried in a [[cadaver tomb]] in [[Saint Denis Basilica]].
In fact, the one known horoscope of Henri II by Gaurico is literally quoted in the ''Dictionnaire'' of [[Pierre Bayle]]. There is no question of a duel. Gaurico promises the best successes to Henri II and adds that he shall live up to the age of 69 year, 10 month and 12 days, provided that he passes the years 56, 63 and 64 of his age.<ref>Pierre Bayle, ''Dictionnaire historique et critique'', ed. Paris, 1820, t. 8, article ''Henri II'', p. 26, available on [https://books.google.com/books?id=GOcOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA26 Google Books], quotation of Gaurico, ''Tractatus astrologicus'', Venice, 1552, folio 42, verso. There exists another version of Gaurico's prophecy, given by Erasmo Pèrcopo, ''L’umanista Pomponio Gaurico. Luca Gaurico ultimo degli astrologi'', Napoli, Luigi Pierro, 1895, p. 159, who refers to [[Gui du Faur de Pibrac]], ''Apologie à la reine Marguerite'', in D'Artigny, ''Mémoires d'histoire, de critique et de littérature'', Paris, 1749, t. II and t. III, pp. 317 and ff. The passage of Pibrac is quoted p. 410 of volume II of D'Artigny's book and in vol. III, pp. 317 and ff., D'Artigny argues against the authenticity of the prediction attributed by Pibrac to Gaurico. See David Clement, ''Bibliothèque curieuse'', t. 9, chez Jean Guillaume Schmid, 1760, available on [https://books.google.com/books?id=ES4VAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA87 Google Books]</ref>
In regard to the birth of [[Martin Luther]], Gaurico found a connection between this date (November 10, 1483, according to the reckoning of the [[Gregorian Calendar]]) and a "[[grand conjunction]]," that is, a meeting of the planets [[Jupiter]] and [[Saturn]]. Grand conjunctions were meant to predict extensive changes in the secular and religious power structures. Because the “grand conjunction” of 1484 took place in the sign of [[Scorpius|Scorpio]], an astrological sign that stood for radical, revolutionary events as well as for epidemics and widespread death, this indicated to Gaurico that dramatic changes would occur in all social spheres –such as would result from the [[Protestant Reformation|Reformation]].<ref>[http://www.esoteric.msu.edu/VolumeVI/Schoener.htm The Coming of a 'Little Prophet': Astrological Pamphlets and the Reformation]. Esoteric.msu.edu. Retrieved on 2011-10-01.</ref>
Gaurico has been identified by the historian Paola Zambelli as the author of an anonymous 1512 pamphlet that predicted a university deluge to take place in 1524 as a result of a conjunction of the superior planets in the watery sign of Pisces.<ref>Paola Zambelli, "Many Ends for the World," in ''‘Astrologi hallucinati‘: Stars and the End of the World in Luther's Time'' (New York, 1986).</ref>
==Astrology and buildings== [[File:Gaurico - Ephemerides recognitae et ad unguem castigatae, 1533 - 133671.jpg|thumb|''Ephemerides recognitae et ad unguem castigatae'', 1533]] [[Image:Gaurico - Super diebus decretoriis quos etiam criticos vocitant axiomata, 1546 - 1500210.jpg|thumb|''Super diebus decretoriis quos etiam criticos vocitant axiomata'', 1546]]
Gaurico was widely renowned as an astrologer, and his ''Tractatus Astrologicus'' (1552) also contained charts of the foundation of various buildings and cities. Pope Paul III thus used Gaurico to determine the most auspicious time at which the cornerstone of a new building in the neighborhood of [[St Peter's Basilica]] should be laid. It is said that Gaurico arrived at the scene in great pomp. An assistant, the astrologer Vincentius Campanatius of [[Bologna]], was commanded to inspect the sky with an [[astrolabe]] and cry out in a loud voice the best time when the moment to lay the first marble slab arrived.<ref>[http://www.meta-religion.com/Esoterism/Astrology/success.htm Success – And The Beginning Of Failure]. Meta-religion.com. Retrieved on 2011-10-01.</ref>
==Legacy== Gaurico ran a school of [[astrology]] at [[Ferrara]]. One of his pupils was [[Julius Caesar Scaliger]]. As a scholar, Gaurico edited [[George of Trebizon|George of Trebizon's]] translation of [[Ptolemy|Ptolemy's]] ''[[Almagest]]'', a work Gaurico dedicated to Pope [[Nicholas V]], who had commissioned the work. Gaurico theorized that Ptolemy was a native of [[Pelusium]].<ref>[http://www.er.uqam.ca/nobel/r14310/Ptolemy/Ziletti.html Ptolemy: Iconography of His Portrait – Ptolémée: Iconographie de son portrait]. Er.uqam.ca. Retrieved on 2011-10-01.</ref>
The [[lunar crater]] [[Gauricus (crater)|Gauricus]] is named after him.
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.esoteric.msu.edu/VolumeVI/Schoener.htm Gustav-Adolf Schoener, The Coming of a “Little Prophet”: Astrological Pamphlets and the Reformation] *[http://www.renaissanceastrology.com/astrologyinrenaissancetwo.html Renaissance Astrology] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061021084129/http://www.santiagobovisio.com/ing/books/book16.htm Santiago Bovisio: HISTORY OF THE ESOTERIC ORDERS] *[http://hos.ou.edu/galleries//16thCentury/Gaurico/ Online Galleries, History of Science Collections, University of Oklahoma Libraries] High resolution images of works by and/or portraits of Luca Gaurico in .jpg and .tiff format.
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
{{other people}} {{Infobox CanadianMP | honorific-prefix = | name = Lynn McDonald | honorific-suffix = {{post-nominals|country=CAN|CM|size=100%}} | image = Lynn McDonald fmr MP Broadview--Greenwood 2009-bw.jpg |caption = Lecturing in Toronto, November 2009 | riding = [[Broadview-Greenwood]] | parliament = Canadian | term_start = 1982 | term_end = 1988 | predecessor = [[Bob Rae]] | successor = [[Dennis Mills]] | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1940|07|15}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | party = [[New Democratic Party (Canada)|New Democrat]] | spouse = | children = | nationality = [[Canadians|Canadian]] | residence = [[Toronto]], Ontario, Canada | profession = Professor | religion = [[Anglican]] | footnotes = }} '''Lynn McDonald''' {{post-nominals|country=CAN|CM}} (born July 15, 1940) is a university professor, anti-tobacco activist and former member of the [[House of Commons of Canada]]. She is a former president of the [[National Action Committee on the Status of Women]] and was the [[New Democratic Party (Canada)|New Democratic Party]] (NDP) [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Broadview—Greenwood]] from 1982 until 1988. McDonald is a professor emerita of [[sociology]] at the [[University of Guelph]].
==Political career== McDonald's first run for public office was during the [[Ontario general election, 1981|1981 provincial election]] when she was the [[Ontario New Democratic Party]]'s candidate in the [[Riding (division)|riding]] of [[Oriole (provincial electoral district)|Oriole]] in [[North York, Ontario|North York]].
The next year, she entered federal politics and was elected in the [[by-election]] held to fill the vacancy created by [[Bob Rae]]'s departure from federal politics to take the leadership of the Ontario NDP. She defeated senior party aide [[Gerald Caplan]] on the third ballot to win the NDP nomination. In the by-election she defeated former ''[[Toronto Sun]]'' editor [[Peter Worthington]], who was running as an [[independent (politician)|independent]], by almost 2,000 votes. In the [[Canadian federal election, 1984|1984 federal election]], she increased her margin to over 3,500 votes again defeating Worthington who, this time, was running as the official [[Progressive Conservative Party of Canada|Progressive Conservative]] candidate.
In Parliament, McDonald championed women's equality (she was the first Member of Parliament to be addressed as [[Ms.]]) and was also a notable opponent of smoking. She earned the enmity of the [[tobacco industry]] by moving a [[private member's bill]] to restrict smoking and ban tobacco advertising and sponsorships.<ref>The Battle to Ban Advertising. The International Development Research Centre. {{cite web |url=http://reseau.crdi.ca/en/ev-28820-201-1-DO_TOPIC.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-01-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120720212957/http://reseau.crdi.ca/en/ev-28820-201-1-DO_TOPIC.html |archivedate=2012-07-20 |df= }}, Last accessed, December 19, 2009</ref>
Bill C-204, the ''Non-smokers' Health Act'', was introduced by McDonald in October 1986 and proposed to restrict smoking in federally regulated workplaces as well as on planes, trains and boats. The Bill also would have banned tobacco advertising and sponsorships and regulated sales by listed tobacco products under the ''Hazardous Products Act''.
McDonald's bill was short-listed by a parliamentary committee for debate on the floor of the house and succeeded in winning growing support from MPs from all sides of the House of Commons as health groups lobbied in its favour. On April 22, 1987, ten days prior to the Bill's scheduled [[second reading]] vote, [[Minister of Health (Canada)|Health Minister]] [[Jake Epp]] announced the government's intention to introduce a bill that would ban tobacco advertising and sponsorships and strengthen health warnings on cigarette packages. The government also announced that it would prohibit smoking in government buildings and restrict it in other federally regulated workplaces.
Despite intense lobbying by the tobacco industry, both McDonald's bill and Epp's Bill C-51, were passed by parliament and given [[royal assent]] on June 28, 1988. The lobbying around McDonald's bill is credited with giving Epp the political motivation to introduce his own legislation. McDonald's bill passed in a [[free vote]] despite the fact that every member of Cabinet present in the House voted against it.
McDonald was defeated in the [[Canadian federal election, 1988|1988 federal election]] by [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberal]] [[Dennis Mills]] by 1,200 votes. She attempted a comeback against Mills in the [[Canadian federal election, 1993|1993 federal election]], but was defeated by almost 10,000 votes as support for the NDP collapsed nationwide.<ref>Whitehorn 52.</ref>
McDonald has since been active on environmental issues, initially with the Campaign for Nuclear Phaseout, and lately as co-founder of JustEarth: A Coalition for Environmental Justice,<ref>About JustEarth [http://www.justearth.net/about-justearth] (JustEarth official website). Last accessed March 08, 2012.</ref> which works on climate change; she is a member of the Board of Directors of Climate Action Network Canada. Since 2011 McDonald has been campaigning for an electoral alliance for the 2015 federal election, to lead to proportional representation; she is a co-founder of the Canadian Electoral Alliance.
She was named a [[Member of the Order of Canada]] in 2015.<ref>[http://thechronicleherald.ca/canada/1296405-four-nova-scotians-among-order-of-canada-honourees "Four Nova Scotians among Order of Canada honourees"]. ''[[The Chronicle-Herald]]'', July 1, 2015.</ref>
==Writing== McDonald is the author of a number of books and scholarly articles including ''The Early Origins of the Social Sciences'' (Montreal: McGill-Queen's University Press, 1993), ''Women Founders of the Social Sciences'' (Ottawa: Carleton University Press, 1994), ''and Women Theorists on Society and Politics'' (Waterloo: Wilfrid Laurier University Press 1998). She is the director of ''The Collected Works of Florence Nightingale'', a 16-volume edition of [[Florence Nightingale]]'s books, articles, pamphlets and previously unpublished correspondence, gathered from more than 200 archives worldwide. Publication, by Wilfrid Laurier University Press, began with volume 1 in 2001, and ended with volume 16 in 2012.<ref>WLU Press – Collected Works of Florence Nightingale {{cite web |url=http://www.wlu.ca/press/Series/CWFN.shtml |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-03-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110814003527/http://www.wlu.ca/press/Series/CWFN.shtml |archivedate=2011-08-14 |df= }}. Last accessed March 08, 2012.</ref>
She is co-founder of ''The Nightingale Society'' which promotes the legacy of [[Florence Nightingale]].
==Notes==
{{Reflist}}
==References==
* Whitehorn, Alan. "The NDP's Quest for Survival," in ''The Canadian General Election of 1993.'' ed. Alan Frizzell, Jon H. Pammett, and Anthony Westell. Ottawa: Carleton University Press, 1994.
==External links== *{{Canadian Parliament links|ID=10059}} *[https://archive.is/20120720212957/http://reseau.crdi.ca/en/ev-28820-201-1-DO_TOPIC.html The Battle to Ban Advertising] on Bill C-204 and Bill C-51 *[http://www.uoguelph.ca/~cwfn/ The Collected Works of Florence Nightingale] project homepage *[http://www.nightingalesociety.com The Nightingale Society] *[http://www.justearth.net Just Earth: A Coalition for Environmental Justice] *[http://www.electoralalliance.ca Canadian Electoral Alliance]
{{Authority control}}

{{Infobox Chinese-language singer and actor <!------See WikiProject Chinese-language entertainment-------> | name = Ma Sanli | native_name = ﻣَﺎ صً لِ | image = | caption = | chinesename = | tradchinesename = {{linktext|馬|三|立}} | simpchinesename = {{linktext|马|三|立}} | pinyinchinesename = Mǎ Sānlì | origin = | birth_date = 1 October 1914 | birth_place = [[Beijing]], [[China]] |death_date = {{death date and age|2003|2|11|1914|10|1|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Tianjin]], China | occupation = [[Xiangsheng]] actor | spouse = | awards = | website = }} {{Chinese name|[[Ma (surname)|Ma]]}} '''Ma Sanli''' ([[Xiao'erjing]]: {{lang|zh-Arab|ﻣَﺎ صً لِ }}， {{zh|t={{linktext|馬|三|立}}|s={{linktext|马|三|立}}|p=Mǎ Sānlì}}; 1914 – 11 February 2003) was a [[China|Chinese]] comedian in the traditional [[Xiangsheng]] or "crosstalk" style.<ref>[http://www.topbeijingtravel.com/beijing-entertainment/chinese-cross-talk.htm Xiangsheng Artists: Ma Sanli]</ref>
==Biography== Ma was born in [[Beijing]]; he was of the [[Hui people|Hui]] ethnic group, and the son and grandson of practitioners of Xiangsheng. He was apprenticed to [[Zhou Deshan]] in 1929. Ma was a Chinese [[Muslim]], his faith being [[Islam]].
He came to be noted for avoiding complication in a way that kept his performances accessible to a mass audience. He pursued his art in [[Tianjin]].
He became a widower in 1984. In December 2001, Ma retired from the Xiangsheng trade.
On 11 February 2003, he died in Tianjin after a long battle with [[cancer]].<ref>[http://ent.sina.com.cn/f/maslbs/index.shtml 相声泰斗马三立辞世 (Ma Sanli Dies at 90)]</ref><ref name="China News" />
== Works == * Nonsense * Drunken old man * Chasing * Car horn * Health check * The charm of the comic * Recipe * Eat dumplings * Sloppy * Eighty-one floor * Write Pair * Meeting the fans * Physiognomy * Emotional and health * Xijiangyue * Boast Residential * Remedies * Pairs * Three Character Classic * Pull foreign films * Buying Monkeys * Meeting Fiend * Yellow Crane Tower<ref name="China News">[http://www.china.org.cn/english/2003/Mar/57171.htm Cross Talker Ma Sanli and Traditional Chinese Culture]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20121212221711/http://www.chinaculture.org/gb/en_artqa/2003-09/24/content_40224.htm Ma Sanli Biodata]
{{Authority control}}

'''Man of the Hole''' ({{lang-pt|índio do buraco}}) is a [[nickname]] used by officials<ref name="Revealing"/> and the media to describe a man who is [[Indigenous peoples in Brazil|indigenous to Brazil]] and lives alone in the [[Amazon rainforest]]. He is believed to be the last surviving member of his tribe.<ref name="survival international">[https://www.survivalinternational.org/articles/3105-the-last-of-his-tribe The last of his tribe] by Fiona Watson; survivalinternational.org</ref> It is unknown what language he speaks or what his tribe was called.<ref name="survival international"/><ref name="cracked">[https://www.cracked.com/article_19976_6-isolated-groups-who-had-no-idea-that-civilization-existed.html 6 Isolated Groups Who Had No Idea That Civilization Existed] by C. Coville; 17 August 2012; [[cracked.com]]</ref>
==Name== The Man of the Hole's nickname derives from the deep hole found in each home that he has abandoned. It was originally believed that these holes were used to trap animals or for him to hide in,<ref name="survival international"/><ref name="telegraph">[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/southamerica/brazil/6784429/Man-in-the-Hole-lone-survivor-of-Amazon-tribe-hunted-by-Brazilian-ranchers.html Man in the Hole: lone survivor of Amazon tribe hunted by Brazilian ranchers]; 11 December 2009; telegraph.co.uk</ref><ref name="slate">[https://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/dispatches/2010/08/the_most_isolated_man_on_the_planet.single.html The Most Isolated Man on the Planet] by [[Monte Reel]]; 2010; slate.com</ref> but some observers have also speculated that they might have been of spiritual significance to his old tribe.<ref name="Revealing">{{cite news |url=https://www.nationalgeographic.com/culture-exploration/2018/08/brazil-uncontacted-tribe-indigenous-people-amazon-video/ |title=Why Revealing Uncontacted Tribes May Help Save Them |author=Scott Wallace |work=[[National Geographic]] |date=31 August 2018 |accessdate=2 September 2018}}</ref> The holes are narrow<ref name="Revealing"/> and over 6 feet (1.8 meters) deep.<ref name="survival international"/>
He has also been referred to as: * the '''indigenous man in the hole'''<ref name="The Guardian">{{cite news |last1=Phillips |first1=Dom |title=Footage of sole survivor of Amazon tribe emerges |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jul/19/footage-sole-survivor-amazon-tribe-emerges-brazil |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=8 September 2018 |language=en |date=19 July 2018}}</ref> * the '''Man in the Hole'''<ref name="telegraph"/> * the '''Last of his Tribe'''<ref name="survival international"/> * the '''Last Tribesman'''<ref>[https://mysteriousuniverse.org/2014/06/the-last-tribesman/ The Last Tribesman] by Brent Swancer; 20 June 2014; mysteriousuniverse.org</ref> * the '''Loneliest Man on Earth'''<ref name="cracked"/> * the '''lone survivor'''<ref name="Revealing"/>
==Biography== Other people first became aware of the Man of the Hole's isolated existence in 1996.<ref name="Revealing"/><ref name="slate"/> The rest of his tribe was probably killed in a number of clashes with ranchers and loggers in the 1980s and 1990s, with one expert explaining that "he should not be seen as a recluse hiding from society. The man is the survivor of a genocide. He didn't choose to live alone."<ref name="Revealing"/> In 2007, the Brazilian government's [[Fundação Nacional do Índio]] (FUNAI) "declared a 31-square-mile [8,029 hectare] area around him off-limits to trespassing and development."<ref name="slate"/> His territory was later expanded by 11.5 square miles (3,000 hectares).<ref name="survival international"/> [[Constitution of Brazil|Brazil's constitution]], ratified in 1988, had already granted indigenous people rights to lands they had traditionally inhabited.<ref name="cracked"/><ref name="slate"/> Since the reserve's establishment, FUNAI has monitored him and tried to prevent intrusions into his area.<ref name="Revealing"/> Despite this, the Man of the Hole was attacked by gunmen in 2009 but managed to survive.<ref name="telegraph"/><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/dec/09/amazon-man-in-hole-attacked Amazon's 'man of the hole' attacked by unknown gunmen] by Rory Carroll; 9 December 2009; theguardian.com</ref><ref>{{cite web|title='Man in the Hole', lone survivor of Amazon tribe massacre, escapes ranchers' bullets|url=https://www.amazonrainforestnews.com/2009/12/man-in-hole-lone-survivor-of-amazon.html|website=Amazon Rainforest News|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170318115513/https://www.amazonrainforestnews.com/2009/12/man-in-hole-lone-survivor-of-amazon.html|archivedate=March 18, 2017|date=December 11, 2009}}</ref><ref>[https://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2009/12/10/amazons-man-hole-attacked-unknown-gunmen-78538 Amazon's 'man of the hole' attacked by unknown gunmen]; 10 December 2009; indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com</ref>
Though he has avoided further direct contact with others, the Man of the Hole is aware that he is monitored by FUNAI. The agency occasionally left gifts of tools and seeds for him, and thus "engendered a certain level of trust". He sometimes signals to observing teams to avoid pitfalls he dug either as defense or to trap animals. In 2018, FUNAI released a video of him in order to raise global awareness of the threats to the uncontacted peoples in Brazil.<ref name="Revealing"/> In the video, the man, now believed to be in his 50s, appeared to be in good health.<ref name="The Guardian"/>
==See also== * [[Uncontacted peoples]] * [[Indigenous peoples in Brazil]] * [[Ishi]], the last of his tribe in North America
==References== <references />
==External links== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ngVW6sRDc1k The Man of the Hole; New Scientist; video]
[[Category:Uncontacted peoples]] [[Category:Indigenous peoples in Brazil]] [[Category:Unidentified people]] [[Category:Possibly living people]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:Last living survivors]]

'''Michael Pelligrino''' (born 1966) is a [[United States|U.S.]] man who fooled publisher [[Simon & Schuster]] into thinking that he was ''Michael Gambino'', grandson of [[American Mafia|Mafioso]] [[Carlo Gambino]].<ref>{{cite news|title=How I was duped by the don who was a con|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/1405966/How-I-was-duped-by-the-don-who-was-a-con.html|accessdate=11 April 2016|publisher=The Telegraph|date=September 1, 2002}}</ref>
In 1999, Pelligrino was jailed for [[theft]] and impersonating an [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] agent. In jail he contacted literary agent Joel Gotler of the [[Artist Management Group]], a [[talent agency]] in [[Hollywood]], and convinced him that he was actually Michael Gambino, illegitimate grandson of Carlo Gambino. When he was released in 2001, Gotler sold his story to [[Pocket Books]], a division of Simon & Schuster, for a $500,000 advance.<ref>{{cite news|title=Publisher falls for a wise guy's sting|url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2002/08/29/1030508097666.html|accessdate=11 April 2016|publisher=The Guardian|date=August 30, 2002}}</ref>
Pelligrino used a [[ghostwriter]] to make a book ''The Honored Society'', a novel that was supposedly based on his own experiences as a [[gangster]]. In the book he claimed that he had been 12 years in prison for [[bribery]], [[gambling]], [[extortion]], [[kidnapping]], [[money laundering]], [[murder]] and [[pimping]] and had decided to come clean when serving time. The book was published in November 2001. Pelligrino appeared on ''[[Good Morning America]]'' to promote his book. He claimed that he was a son of Carlo Gambino's unknown son Vito, who had been born in Sicily and later immigrated to the United States.<ref>{{cite news|title=Publisher sues over Mafia credentials|url=http://money.cnn.com/2002/08/29/news/mafia/index.htm|accessdate=11 April 2016|publisher=CNN|date=August 29, 2002}}</ref>
As it happens, Carlo Gambino has a great-grandson named Michael, who lives in New York. Carlo Gambino's son [[Thomas Gambino]] instructed his own lawyer Michael Rosen to expose the impostor. Rosen contacted the publisher to inform them.
Simon & Schuster withdrew the book. On August 27, 2002, Simon & Schuster sued Artist Management Group, accusing it of misrepresenting Michael Gambino and demanding return of the money and millions of dollars in damages. Pelligrino's lawyers defended their client by stating that he did believe he was Gambino's grandson and that the book was fiction, not a biography.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Burkeman|first1=Oliver|title=The Codfather and the offer a publisher should have refused|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2002/aug/29/books.pressandpublishing|accessdate=11 April 2016|publisher=The Guardian|date=August 29, 2002}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}'''''Reel Rome''''' is the story of a Canadian Language Teacher who accidentally meets Italy’s hottest celebrity on a Roman film set and is offered to Write a Hollywood script for the twisted Playboy Actor. '''(Based on a True Story). [http://www.englishtraining.it/ www.englishtraining.it]'''
{{DEFAULTSORT:Pelligrino, Michael}} [[Category:1966 births]] [[Category:Literary forgeries]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Impostors]] [[Category:Organized crime memoirists]]

{{Infobox Officeholder |honorific-prefix = [[The Right Honourable]] |name = The Viscount Ullswater |honorific-suffix = {{postnominals|country=GBR|size=100%|LVO|PC}} |image = Official portrait of Viscount Ullswater crop 2.jpg |office = [[Secretary of State for Environment|Minister of State for Environment and Countryside]] |primeminister = [[John Major]] |term_start = 20 July 1994 |term_end = 6 July 1995 |predecessor = [[Robert Atkins (politician)|Robert Atkins]] |successor = [[ Robert Shirley, 13th Earl Ferrers|The earl Ferrers]] |office1 =[[Chief Whip|Government Chief Whip in the House of Lords]]
[[Captain of the Honourable Corps of Gentlemen-at-Arms]] |primeminister1 = [[John Major]] |term_start1 = 16 September 1993 |term_end1 = 20 July 1994 |predecessor1 = [[Alexander Fermor-Hesketh, 3rd Baron Hesketh|The Lord Hesketh]] |successor1 = [[Thomas Galbraith, 2nd Baron Strathclyde|The Lord Strathclyde]] |office3 = [[Lord-in-waiting]]
[[Government Whip]] |primeminister3 = [[Margaret Thatcher]] |term_start3 = 26 July 1989 |term_end3 = 22 July 1990 |predecessor3 = [[Oliver Eden, 8th Baron Henley|The Lord Henley]] |successor3 = [[Hugh Mackay, 14th Lord Reay|The Lord Reay]] |office2 = [[ Secretary of State for Employment|Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for Employment]] |primeminister2 = [[Margaret Thatcher]]
[[John Major]] |term_start2 = 24 July 1990 |term_end2 = 16 September 1993 |predecessor2 = [[ Thomas Galbraith, 2nd Baron Strathclyde|The Lord Strathclyde]] |successor2 = [[ Oliver Eden, 8th Baron Henley|The Lord Henley]] |office4 =[[Member of the House of Lords]]
[[Lord Temporal]] |term_start4 = 1 April 2003
as an [[List of elected hereditary peers under the House of Lords Act 1999|excepted hereditary peer]] |majority4 = |predecessor4 = [[George Makgill, 13th Viscount of Oxfuird|The Viscount of Oxfuird]] |successor4 = |term_start5 = 24 July 1963 |term_end5 = 11 November 1999
as a [[hereditary peer]] |predecessor5 = [[James Lowther, 1st Viscount Ullswater]] |successor5 = Seat Abolished
([[House of Lords Act 1999]]) |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1942|1|9|df=y}} |birth_place = |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] |alma_mater = [[Trinity College, Cambridge]] }} '''Nicholas James Christopher Lowther, 2nd Viscount Ullswater''' {{postnominals|country=GBR|LVO|PC}} (born 9 January 1942), succeeded his great-grandfather in the Viscountcy of Ullswater in 1949, sitting in the [[House of Lords]] as a [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]]. He is one of very few peers to have succeeded a great-grandfather in a title. ==Education== He was educated at [[Eton College]] and [[Trinity College, Cambridge]]. ==Political career== Lord Ullswater was made a [[Lord-in-waiting]] ([[whip]]) in January 1989 by [[Margaret Thatcher]] before becoming Parliamentary Under Secretary of State at the [[Department of Employment]] in July 1990. He was retained by [[John Major]] in that role until 1993, when he became [[Captain of the Honourable Corps of Gentlemen at Arms]] (Government Chief Whip in the House of Lords). He remained in this role for a year when he became Minister of State for the Environment in 1994 (as well as a [[Privy Council of the United Kingdom|Privy Counsellor]]) in 1994, but he left the Government in a 1995 reshuffle. ==Princess Margaret== In 1998, he became the Private Secretary to [[Princess Margaret, Countess of Snowdon]] and continued in this office until her death in 2002. He was appointed Lieutenant of the [[Royal Victorian Order]] in the [[2002 Demise Honours|special Honours List]] issued by the Queen after Princess Margaret's demise. ==Return to politics== As a member of a [[Royal Household]] he could not take part in partisan politics and did not seek to remain in the [[House of Lords]] when the [[House of Lords Act 1999]] was passed. But after the death of the [[George Makgill, 13th Viscount of Oxfuird|Viscount of Oxfuird]] in January 2003, he won the all-house by-election, enabling him to return to the House of Lords. On 22 May 2006, Lord Ullswater was nominated for the newly created post of [[Lord Speaker]], and in the election held on 28 June 2006 emerged in third place out of nine candidates. His great-grandfather, [[James William Lowther, 1st Viscount Ullswater|James Lowther]], served as [[Speaker of the British House of Commons|Speaker of the House of Commons]] 1905–1921. ==Titles and Styles and Arms== *1942: Mr Nicholas Lowther *1942–1949: ''[[The Honourable|The Hon]]'' Nicholas Lowther *1949–1994: ''[[The Right Honourable|The Rt Hon]]'' The Viscount Ullswater *1992–2002: ''[[The Right Honourable|The Rt Hon]]'' The Viscount Ullswater PC *2002–: ''[[The Right Honourable|The Rt Hon]]'' The Viscount Ullswater LVO PC ===Arms=== {{Infobox COA wide |image = [[File:Coronet of a British Viscount.svg|centre|150px]][[File:Ullswater Escutcheon.png|centre|200px]] |crest = A Dragon passant Argent |coronet = A [[Coronet|Coronet of a Viscount]] |escutcheon = Or six Annulets three two and one a Crescent for difference |supporters = On either side a Horse Argent gorged with a Wreath of Laurel Vert and charged on the shoulder with a Portcullis chained Or |motto = Magistratum Indicat Virum (The office shows the man) }} ==Personal life== Lord Ullswater was an amateur jockey in his youth. He has two sons and two daughters: *Hon. Emma Mary Lowther, (b. 1968) *Hon. Clare Priscilla Lowther, (b. 1970) *Hon. Benjamin James Lowther (b. 1975) *Hon. Edward John Lowther (b. 1981) ==References== *{{Rayment|date=February 2012}} *{{cite web | url=http://www.psr.keele.ac.uk/table/york/ | title=Keele University Political Science Resources | accessdate=2007-07-07}} *{{cite web | url=http://www.parliament.uk/about_lords/lord_speaker/election2006.cfm | title=Lord Speaker election | accessdate=2007-07-07 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070318114934/http://www.parliament.uk/about_lords/lord_speaker/election2006.cfm | archivedate=2007-03-18 | df= }} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef |before=[[Alexander Fermor-Hesketh, 3rd Baron Hesketh|The Lord Hesketh]]}} {{s-ttl |title=[[Chief Whip#United Kingdom|Chief Whip]] in the [[House of Lords]]
[[Captain of the Honourable Corps of Gentlemen-at-Arms]] |years=1993–1994}} {{s-aft |after=[[Thomas Galbraith, 2nd Baron Strathclyde|The Lord Strathclyde]]}} {{s-ppo}} {{s-bef |before=[[Alexander Fermor-Hesketh, 3rd Baron Hesketh|The Lord Hesketh]]}} {{s-ttl |title=[[Conservative Chief Whip#House of Lords|Conservative Chief Whip in the House of Lords]] |years=1993–1994}} {{s-aft |after=[[Thomas Galbraith, 2nd Baron Strathclyde|The Lord Strathclyde]]}} {{s-reg|uk}} {{s-bef|before=[[James Lowther, 1st Viscount Ullswater|James Lowther]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Viscount Ullswater]]|years=1949–present}} {{s-inc}} {{s-end}} {{Lord Speaker election, 2006}} {{British viscounts}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ullswater, Nicholas}} [[Category:1942 births]] [[Category:Alumni of Trinity College, Cambridge]] [[Category:Courtiers]] [[Category:Conservative Party (UK) Baronesses- and Lords-in-Waiting]] [[Category:Hereditary peers elected under the House of Lords Act]] [[Category:Honourable Corps of Gentlemen at Arms]] [[Category:Lieutenants of the Royal Victorian Order]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of the Privy Council of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:People educated at Eton College]] [[Category:People educated at West Downs School]] [[Category:Viscounts in the Peerage of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Lowther family|Nicholas]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use Indian English|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox judge | honorific-prefix = Justice | name = Sir Pramadacharan Banerjee | honorific-suffix = | image = Pramadacharan_Banerjee.jpg | successor = | office1 = [[Allahabad High Court#Former Justices|Justice, Allahabad High Court]] | nominator1 = | appointer1 = | predecessor1 = | successor1 = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Indian | education = Graduation, LL.B | occupation = | profession = | religion = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = }}
'''Sir Pramada''' (or '''Pramoda''') '''Charan Banerjee''' (sometimes '''Churn''' and '''Banerji''', '''Bannerji''', '''Bannerjee''', '''Banarji''', '''Banarjee''') (1848 – ca. 1930) was a [[Bengali people|Bengali]] Indian jurist of the [[British Raj]] era in the [[Allahabad High Court]] and also [[Vice-Chancellor]] of the [[University of Allahabad]].
Banerjee was born on 10 April 1848. He lived in [[Uttarpara]] and attended [[Presidency College, Kolkata|Presidency College, Calcutta]] and the [[University of Calcutta]], from which he respectively obtained [[B.A.]] and [[B.L.]] degrees. He practised at the [[Bar (law)|Bar]] in [[Bankipore]] until moving to [[Allahabad]] in 1870.<ref name="abanerji" /><ref name="liberation" />
Banerjee first entered the judiciary of India in January 1872 as a [[munsif]], working at Allahabad, [[Benares]] and [[Ghazipore]]. He was appointed a [[subordinate judge]] in 1880, working first in the [[Small Causes Court]]s of [[Agra]], where he was the first Indian judge,<ref name="abanerji" /> and then at Allahabad. He held a brief appointment as an additional civil judge at [[Lucknow]] in 1893 before becoming a [[puisne judge]] for the [[North-Western Provinces]] at Allahabad High Court in December of that year.<ref name="liberation">{{cite journal |journal=The Liberal and The New Dispensation |location=Calcutta |date=17 December 1873 |volume=XII |issue=50 |page=4 |title=Notes and Comments |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3KopAAAAYAAJ&pg=PT389}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=The India List and India Office List |author=India Office, United Kingdom |publisher=Harrison and Sons |location=London |year=1905 |page=591 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=b2NPAAAAMAAJ}}</ref> He remained in that office until August 1923, when he was replaced by Kanhaiya Lal prior to retiring from the bench in March 1924.<ref name="abanerji">{{cite web |first=Amitav |last=Banerji |url=http://www.allahabadhighcourt.in/event/SriPramodaCBanerjeeABanerji.pdf |title=Sir Pramoda Charan Banerjee |format=PDF |publisher=Allahabad High Court |accessdate=2014-08-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Imperial and Foreign News Items |newspaper=The Times |location=London, England |date=19 September 1923 |page=9 |issue=43450}}</ref>
Banerjee was the second Indian to be appointed a judge at the Allahabad High Court, the first being [[Syed Mahmood]].{{efn|Between 1876 and 1910 there were 29 judges who sat in the Allahabad High Court, of which 25 were British. Two of the remainder, including Mahmood, were Muslims whose opinions were rarely accepted by the full bench.<ref name="Kozlowski">{{cite book |title=Muslim Endowments and Society in British India |first=Gregory C. |last=Kozlowski |edition=Reprinted |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=2008 |isbn=978-0-521-08867-1 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9I2JbchpdMMC |pages=118–119}}</ref>}} Mahmood had retired from the Court in the face of accusations that his chronic drunkenness was affecting his ability and it was his place that Banerjee took.<ref name="Kozlowski" /><ref>{{London Gazette |issue=26467 |date=15 December 1893 |page=7319}}</ref> With Mahmood, Chief Justice [[John Edge]] and others, he "made indelible imprints greatness as Judges on the pages of [Allahabad High Court’s] law reports".<ref>{{cite web |first=Nasirullah |last=Beg |url=http://www.allahabadhighcourt.in/event/Welcome_Address_NU_Beg25-11-66.pdf |title=Welcome Address |format=PDF |date=25 November 1966 |publisher=Allahabad High Court}}</ref>
Appointed a [[Knight Bachelor]] in the 1913 [[Birthday Honours]],<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=28733 |date=1 July 1913 |page=4638}}</ref> Banerjee was a member of the law faculty at the University of Allahabad and was Vice-Chancellor of the university from 1917 to 1919,<ref>{{cite web |title=Ex- Vice Chancellor |publisher=University of Allahabad |url=http://www.allduniv.ac.in/index.php/about-us/introduction/ex-vc-list |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130204112621/http://www.allduniv.ac.in/index.php/about-us/introduction/ex-vc-list |archivedate=4 February 2013}}</ref> in which year the university conferred on him the degree of Doctor of Laws, ''[[honoris causa]]'';<ref name="abanerji" /> later, it also established the P. C. Banerjee Hostel in honour of him.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allduniv.ac.in/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=141&Itemid=378 |title=History |publisher=University of Allahabad}}</ref> In 1921, he was awarded the [[Kaisar-i-Hind Medal]], first class, by [[George V]] in recognition of his public service.<ref>{{cite news |title=Kaisar-I-Hind Medal |newspaper=The Times |location=London, England |date=1 January 1921 |page=9 |issue=42607}}</ref>
Banerjee died at the age of 82.<ref name="abanerji" /> Among his children was Lalit Mohan Banerjee, who also served as a judge in the Allahabad High Court.<ref>{{cite news |title=Mr. Justice Banarjee |newspaper=The Times |location=London, England |date=20 October 1932 |page=19 |issue=46269}}</ref>
==Recognition== [[Allahabad University]] established the Sir Pramada Charan Banerjee [[hostel]] in 1915 in his memory.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allduniv.ac.in/?option=com_k2&view=item&layout=item&id=786 |title=Sir PCB Hostel |quote=Hindi text: Sir P. C. Banerjee Hostel (established 1915 to pay regard to Sir P. C. Banerjee) organised a centenary function on 2, 3, 4 October 2015" |publisher=University of Allahabad |accessdate=2015-10-06}}</ref>
==References== '''Notes''' {{notelist}} '''Citations''' {{Reflist|2}}
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Banerjee, Pramada Charan}} [[Category:Indian academic administrators]] [[Category:Judges of the Allahabad High Court]] [[Category:Bengali people]] [[Category:1848 births]] [[Category:1930 deaths]] [[Category:University of Calcutta alumni]] [[Category:People from Hooghly district]] [[Category:Knights Bachelor]] [[Category:Indian knights]] [[Category:Recipients of the Kaisar-i-Hind Medal]] [[Category:Presidency University, Kolkata alumni]] [[Category:University of Allahabad faculty]] [[Category:Scholars from Kolkata]]

{{about||the priest|Richard Kingston (priest)|the football goalkeeper|Richard Kingson}} '''Richard Kingston''' (1635? – 1710?) was an English political pamphleteer, clerical impostor, and spy. [[File:Richard Kingston (17th century).jpg|thumb|Richard Kingston, engraving from 1800.]]
==Life== He was born about 1635. According to his own statements he was a M.A., and was ordained by the [[Bishop of Galloway]], 17 July 1662, at Westminster; and on 6 February 1682 was made chaplain [[in ordinary]] to Charles II. But [[Matthew Smith (informer)|Matthew Smith]] in 1700, when engaged with Kingston in a political controversy, charged him with having forged his letters of orders.<ref name="DNB">{{cite DNB|wstitle=Kingston, Richard}}</ref> [[Sir Jonathan Trelawny, 3rd Baronet|Jonathan Trelawny]] in the 1680s, and [[Thomas Tenison]] in the 1690s, had become aware that Kingston was an impostor. He ceased to wear clerical dress. When Kingston published on the subject in 1700, he made an unconvincing case. He was son of a [[Northamptonshire]] farmer, who became a tailor's apprentice.<ref name="ODNB">{{ODNBweb|id=15627|title=Kingston, Richard|first=M. E.|last=Clayton}}</ref>
In 1665, Kingston was minister at [[St. James's, Clerkenwell]], and worked during the [[Great Plague]]; Trelwany believed he was then a tailor, had found sermons, and preached in the absence of the incumbent. He had resigned this preferment before 17 September 1666, and took up a living at [[Irthlingborough]], [[Northamptonshire]], appointed by [[Knollys (family)|Nicholas Knollys]] who called himself 3rd Earl of Banbury. In 1678, he received the living of [[Henbury]] in [[Gloucestershire]], possibly by purchasing the right himself.<ref name="ODNB"/> He asserted that a prebend and a rectory were added to Henbury. He remained there, on a small estate, till the [[Glorious Revolution]], when he sold his property and moved to London.<ref name="DNB"/>
For a period Kingston spied in London for the [[Jacobitism|Jacobites]]. In 1692, he was discovered by the government agent [[John Macky]], and was turned to spy for the other side. By the second half of the 1690s, he was working for [[Sir William Trumbull]], and in the end his cover was blown when he testified in treason trials.<ref name="ODNB"/> He had a pension to write for the government, but it fell into arrears and he descended into poverty. A petition from him dated 1699 states that £600 was due to him.<ref name="DNB"/>
In 1700, Kingston attacked Smith, who had just published his ''Memoirs of Secret Service'', and a controversy ensued: Kingston attributed Smith's works to [[Tom Brown (satirist)|Tom Brown]]. Kingston also intervened in the controversy which raged in 1707–9 about the so-called [[French Prophets]]. In 1707, his attack on Dr. [[John Freind]]'s vindication of the [[Charles Mordaunt, 3rd Earl of Peterborough|Earl of Peterborough]]'s conduct in Spain appeared; he was arrested by order of the [[House of Lords]]. He was, however, released, 19 January 1708, and the attorney-general was instructed to prosecute him.<ref name="DNB"/>
==Works== Kingston wrote:<ref name="DNB"/>
* ''Pillulæ Pestilentiales, a Sermon at St. Paul's'', London, 1665. * ''The Cause and Cure of Offences'', sermon, London, 1682. * ''Vivat Rex'', a sermon preached before the Mayor of Bristol after the discovery of the [[Rye House plot]], London, 1683. * ''God's Sovereignty and Man's Duty asserted'', London, 1688. * ''A True History of the several Designs and Conspiracies against his Majesties Sacred Person and Government from 1688 to 1697'', London, 1698. This work was intended to reinforce the credibility of John Lunt's alleged Lancashire Jacobite plot of 1694.<ref name="ODNB"/> * ''Tyranny detected, and the late Revolution justified'', London, 1699. * ''A Modest Answer to Captain Smith's Immodest Memorial of Secret Service'', London, 1700. * ''Impudence, Lying, and Forgery detected and Chastiz'd'', London, 1700, an answer to Smith, and a source of information respecting Kingston's history. * ''A Discourse on Divine Providence'', London, 1702. * ''Impartial Remarks upon Dr. Freind's Account of the Earl of Peterborough's Conduct in Spain'', London, 1706. * ''Enthusiastick Impostors no Divinely Inspired Prophets'', part i. 1707, part ii. 1709. * ''Apophthegmata Curiosa, or Reflections, Sentences, and Maxims'', London, 1709.
Kingston also mentions that he wrote a work called ''Cursory Remarks''.<ref name="DNB"/>
==Family== Kingston was twice married, as a [[bigamist]], and in 1699 had nine children.<ref name="DNB"/> He left his first wife Elizabeth Webb, and in 1668 eloped with the daughter of Rev. Arthur Leonard of [[Boughton, Northamptonshire]]. He married a second wife Elizabeth, who may have been this daughter.<ref name="ODNB"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
;Attribution {{DNB|wstitle=Kingston, Richard}}
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kingston, Richard}} [[Category:1630s births]] [[Category:1710 deaths]] [[Category:English writers]] [[Category:Impostors]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox serial killer | name = Robert Napper | image = | image_size = | caption = | birthname = Robert Clive Napper | alias = The Green Chain Rapist
The Plumstead Ripper | occupation = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1966|2|25}} | birth_place = [[Erith]], [[London]], [[United Kingdom]] | death_date = | death_place = | cause = | victims = 3 | country = United Kingdom | states = | beginyear = 15 July 1992 | endyear = November 1993 | apprehended = May 1994 | conviction = | sentence = }} '''Robert Clive Napper''' (born 25 February 1966) is a [[British people|British]] serial murderer. He has been convicted of two murders, one manslaughter, two rapes and two attempted rapes. He was remanded in [[Broadmoor Hospital]] indefinitely on 18 December 2008 for the manslaughter of [[Murder of Rachel Nickell|Rachel Nickell]] on 15 July 1992. He was previously convicted of the 1993 double murder of Samantha Bisset and her daughter Jazmine.Sean O'Neill and Adam Fresco [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/crime/article5365060.ece "Inside the mind of Robert Napper",] ''The Times'', 18 December 2008. Napper has been diagnosed with [[paranoid schizophrenia]] as well as [[Asperger syndrome|Asperger's syndrome]]. ==Early life== Robert Napper is the eldest child of Brian Napper, a driving instructor, and his wife Pauline. Born in [[Erith]], [[South East (London sub region)|southeast London]], Napper was brought up in nearby [[Plumstead]]. His background was troubled and dysfunctional. The marriage of his parents was violent and Napper witnessed violent attacks on his mother. His parents divorced when he was 9 and he and his siblings (two brothers and a sister) were placed in foster care and underwent psychiatric treatment.Sandra Laville [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2008/dec/18/robert-napper-clues "Nickell murder: Missed clues that allowed Napper to kill again",] ''The Guardian'', 18 December 2008. The psychiatric counselling Napper had at the [[Maudsley Hospital]] in [[Camberwell]] lasted for six years. At age 13, Napper underwent a personality change after a family friend sexually assaulted him on a camping holiday. The offender was jailed,Richard Edwards, Murray Wardrop and David Millward [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/3813236/Rachel-Nickell-Profile-of-killer-Robert-Napper.html "Rachel Nickell: Profile of killer Robert Napper",] ''Daily Telegraph'', 18 December 2008. but Napper became introverted, obsessively tidy and reclusive, according to his mother. He also bullied his siblings and spied on his sister while she was naked. ==Criminal activities== In 1986, Napper first came to police attention after being convicted of an offence with an airgun. In October 1989,Shenai Raif [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/rachels-killer-caught-by-new-dna-techniques-1203073.html "Rachel's killer caught by new DNA techniques"], Press Association report reproduced on ''The Independent'' website, 18 December 2008 police had rejected information conveyed in a phonecall from Napper's mother that her son had admitted to perpetrating a rape on Plumstead Common. No case apparently matched the evidence. However, it emerged at the time of Napper's second conviction, that a rape of a 30-year-old woman, in front of her children, eight weeks earlier, had been reported to have occurred in a house which backed on to Plumstead Common. At this point, Pauline Napper broke off all contact with her son. On 15 July 1992 on [[Wimbledon Common]], Napper stabbed the young mother [[Murder of Rachel Nickell|Rachel Nickell]] forty-nine times in front of her son Alex, then aged two, who clung on to his mother's body begging her to wake up. Napper was questioned about unsolved attacks on other women during the year, but was eliminated from inquiries.[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/rachel-nickells-killer-finally-brought-to-justice-1203036.html "Rachel Nickell's killer finally brought to justice",] ''The Independent'', 18 December 2008 In November 1993, in the Bisset home in [[Plumstead]], Napper stabbed 27-year-old Samantha Bisset in her neck and chest, killing her, and then sexually assaultedRichard Edwards [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/3832069/Rachel-Nickell-Mistakes-allowed-Robert-Napper-to-kill-Samantha-and-Jazmine-Bisset.html Rachel Nickell: Mistakes allowed Robert Napper to kill Samantha and Jazmine Bisset",] ''Daily Telegraph'', 18 December 2008. and smothered her four-year-old daughter, Jazmine Jemima Bisset.[https://www.findmypast.com/search/results?firstname=jazmine%20jemima%20&firstname_variants=true&lastname=bisset&yearofbirth=1989&yearofbirth_offset=2&yearofdeath=1994&yearofdeath_offset=2 Births and Deaths England and Wales 1984-2006] In her sitting room, Napper mutilated Samantha's body, taking away parts of her body as a trophy. The crime scene was reportedly so grisly that the police photographer assigned to the case was forced to take two years' leave after witnessing it. After a fingerprint belonging to Napper was recovered from Samantha's flat, he was arrested, and charged with the murders of Samantha and Jazmine Bisset, in May 1994. Napper was convicted at the [[Old Bailey]] in October 1995. He also admitted two rapes and two attempted rapes at this time.Sarah White [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7697876.stm "Killer who slipped through the net"], BBC News, 18 December 2008. From the time of the first Old Bailey trial, he has been held at [[Broadmoor Hospital|Broadmoor]]. In December 1995 he was questioned about Nickell's death but denied any involvement. Napper is also believed to be the "Green Chain Rapist", who carried out at least 70 savage attacks across south-east London over a four-year period ending in 1994. The earliest of the 'Green Chain' rapes have been linked to Napper, and were those he admitted to in 1995. Napper is known to have kept detailed records of the sites of potential and actual attacks on women.Richard Edwards, et al. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/3813236/Rachel-Nickell-Profile-of-killer-Robert-Napper.html "Rachel Nickell: Profile of killer Robert Napper"], ''The Telegraph'', 18 December 2008 During the investigation into the rapes, Napper had been eliminated due to his 6' 2" height, as detectives had decided to exclude anyone over 6' based on the description of a 5' 7" rapist. However there are conflicting witness reports of the rapist's height and Napper walked with a stoop. {{Cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/3813201/Rachel-Nickell-The-missed-opportunities-to-catch-killer-Robert-Napper.html |title=Rachel Nickell: The missed opportunities to catch killer Robert Napper |last=Edwards |first=Richard |date=18 Dec 2008 |work=The Telgraph |access-date=28 March 2018}} {{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2008/dec/18/robert-napper-clues |title=Rachel Nickell case: Missed clues that allowed Robert Napper to kill again |last=Laville |first=Sandra |date=18 December 2008 |work=The Guardian |access-date=28 March 2018 |language=en}} The investigation to find Nickell's murderer resulted in the attempted prosecution of an innocent man, Colin Stagg, until, in 2004, advances in DNA profiling revealed Napper's connection to the case. On 18 December 2008, Napper was convicted of the [[manslaughter]] of Rachel Nickell on the grounds of [[diminished responsibility]]. He also admitted to four other attacks on women. Napper was sentenced to be incarcerated indefinitely at [[Broadmoor Hospital]] for the criminally insane. In his summing up at the [[Old Bailey]], [[John Griffith Williams|Mr Justice Griffiths Williams]] said to Napper: "You are on any view a very dangerous man".Sandra Laville, et al. [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2008/dec/18/rachel-nickell-robert-napper-murder-guilty "Rachel Nickell killing: Serial rapist Robert Napper pleads guilty"], ''The Guardian'', 18 December 2008 ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * Laurence J. Alison, Marie Eyre: ''Killer in the Shadows: The Monstrous Crimes of Robert Napper''. Pennant Books 2009, {{ISBN|978-1-906015-49-7}}. * Kevin Brewer: ''Psychology and Crime''. Heinemann Educational Publishers 2000, {{ISBN|978-0-435-80653-8}}. * Paul Britton: ''The Jigsaw Man''. Corgi Books 1998, {{ISBN|978-0-552-14493-3}}. * Colin Evans: ''A Question of Evidence: The Casebook of Great Forensic Controversies, from Napoleon to O.J.'' Wiley 2002, {{ISBN|978-0-471-44014-7}}. * Mike Fielder: ''The Murder of Rachel Nickell''. John Blake 2000, {{ISBN|978-1-85782-338-7}}. * Alex Handscombe: ''Letting Go: A true story of murder, loss and survival by Rachel Nickell’s son''. Harper Element 2017, {{ISBN|978-0008144296}}. * André Handscombe: ''The Last Thursday in July''. Century 1996 / Arrow 1997, {{ISBN|978-0-09-917512-4}}. * David Kessler: ''Rachel Nickell'', House of Solomon Ltd, 2001, {{ISBN|978-1-904037-03-3}}. * Keith Pedder: ''The Rachel Files'', John Blake 2002, {{ISBN|978-1-904034-30-8}}. * Keith Pedder: ''Murder on the Common: The Secret Story of the Murder That Shocked a Nation''. John Blake 2003, {{ISBN|978-1-84454-057-0}}. * Colin Stagg, David Kessler: ''Who Really Killed Rachel?'' Greenzone Publishing 1999, {{ISBN|978-0-9582027-2-5}}. * Colin Stagg, David Kessler: ''The Lizzie James Conspiracy''. House of Solomon 2001, {{ISBN|978-1-904037-00-2}}. * Colin Stagg, Ted Hynds: ''Pariah: Colin Stagg''. Pennant Publishing 2007, {{ISBN|978-1-906015-10-7}}. * Brent E. Turvey: ''Criminal Profiling: An Introduction to Behavioral Evidence Analysis'' Academic Press 2002, {{ISBN|978-0-12-705041-6}}. ==External links== * [https://www.arretsurimages.net/articles/le-crime-de-robert-napper-presse-gb LE CRIME DE ROBERT NAPPER (British Media Coverage of Napper's Crimes)] * [https://www.crimeandinvestigation.co.uk/crime-files/rachel-nickell-case THE RACHEL NICKELL CASE] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Napper, Robert}} [[Category:1966 births]] [[Category:20th-century English criminals]] [[Category:Criminals from London]] [[Category:English murderers of children]] [[Category:English people convicted of manslaughter]] [[Category:English people convicted of murder]] [[Category:English people convicted of rape]] [[Category:English serial killers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Male serial killers]] [[Category:Murder in 1992]] [[Category:Murder in 1993]] [[Category:Murder in London]] [[Category:History of mental health in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:People acquitted by reason of insanity]] [[Category:People convicted of murder by England and Wales]] [[Category:People detained at Broadmoor Hospital]] [[Category:People from Erith]] [[Category:People with Asperger syndrome]] [[Category:People with schizophrenia]]

{{for|the Mughal princess|Roshanara Begum}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Roshanara | image = Underwood-and-underwood-studio-olive-craddock-name-roshanara-early-1920-via-ebay.jpg | image_size = 240px | caption = Roshanara by [[Underwood & Underwood]] | birth_name = Olive Katherine Craddock | birth_date = 22 January 1894 | birth_place = [[Calcutta]], [[British India]] | death_date = 14 July 1926 (aged 32) | death_place = [[Asheville, North Carolina]], United States | death_cause = [[Appendicitis]]<ref name=npg/> | residence = | known_for = | education = | employer = | occupation = dancer | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | footnotes = | nationality = British }} '''Olive Katherine Craddock''' (22 January 1894 – 14 July 1926) was an [[Anglo-Indian]] dancer trained in [[British India]] who danced under the name '''Roshanara'''. She was known for showing central Indian dance techniques in Britain and America. She died in her thirties from [[appendicitis]].<ref name=obit/>
==Biography== Craddock was born on 22 January 1892 in [[Calcutta]]. Her father was John James Nolan Craddock who was Anglo-Indian and her mother was Mabel Mary Ann Adams who was British. She learned to dance in India.<ref name=vam>[https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O1292333/roshanara-print-farro-e/ Roshanara], Victoria and Albert Museum, Retrieved 14 October 2015</ref> before she moved to Britain around 1909. Craddock took the name Roshanara which built on the celebrity of the princess [[Roshanara Begum]].<ref name=npg>{{cite web |url=http://www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/person/mp55949/roshanara-olive-craddock |title=Olive Craddock |date= |accessdate=2015-06-06 |quote= |publisher=[[National Portrait Gallery, London|National Portrait Gallery]] }}</ref>
[[File:Roshanara-by-Robert-Henri-107.jpg|thumb|left|Roshanara by [[Robert Henri]]]] She danced with [[Loie Fuller]]'s company and then undertook training with the Spanish dancer [[Carmen Tórtola Valencia]]. In 1911 she danced in London in [[Oscar Asche]]'s [[Kismet (play)|Kismet]] and then as Zobeide in [[Scheherazade]]. This role was with the [[Ballets Russes]] at [[Covent Garden]]. The following year she appeared with [[Anna Pavlova]]'s dance company as a speciality dancer.<ref name=vam/> She had several dances that were performed using extracts from the 1880s Oriental opera [[Lakmé]]<ref name="Jowitt1989">{{cite book|author=Deborah Jowitt|title=Time and the Dancing Image|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uaECpiO__W8C&pg=PA147|year=1989|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-06627-4|pages=147–148}}</ref> by the French composer [[Léo Delibes]].
Craddock started to work in the United States in 1916 where she appeared in Vaudeville theatres. In 1917 she and Japanese dancer [[Michio Itō]] were the specialty dancers with [[Adolf Bolm]]'s company ''Ballet Intime''.<ref name="Jowitt1989"/> Roshanara also appeared with [[Ratan Devi]] who was a British singer who had been to India to study music. Devi was accompanied by her husband [[Ananda Coomaraswamy]] who was employed by the Boston Museum of Art as an expert on Indian culture. Coomaraswamy wrote about how Roshanara was an authentic [[nautch]] dancer in contrast to [[Ruth St Denis]] who a few years before had shown Indian style dances.<ref name="Jost2011">{{cite book|author=Diana Brenscheidt gen. Jost|title=Shiva Onstage: Uday Shankar's Company of Hindu Dancers and Musicians in Europe and the United States, 1931–38|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y-3NspSRoAAC&pg=PA135|year=2011|publisher=LIT Verlag Münster|isbn=978-3-643-90108-8|pages=135–136}}</ref>
Craddock arrived as an "alien" emigrant in New York in 1923. Craddock taught dancing and the later film star, [[Bette Davis]] was one of her pupils.<ref name=vam/> She died in her thirties on 16 July 1926 in [[Asheville, North Carolina]].<ref name=obit>{{cite news |author= |agency= |title=Roshanara Is Dead. Famous Dancer's Body Is Being Brought Here From Asheville, N.C. |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D01E4DF1331EE3ABC4E52DFB166838D639EDE |quote= |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=16 July 1926 |accessdate=2015-06-06 }}</ref> from appendicitis.<ref name=npg/>
==Works== Roshanara copyrighted ten of her dances.<ref name=copy>[https://viaf.org/viaf/search?query=local.names+all+%22Roshanara%20%22&sortKeys=holdingscount&recordSchema=BriefVIAF Dances], Viaf File, Retrieved 17 October 2015</ref>
==Legacy== Craddock has been compared to the American dancer [[Ruth St. Denis]] who popularised oriental style dances in America. Although Craddock had been trained in India she devoted her time to improving the perfection of her dance. Ruth St. Denis was inspired by Oriental style dance and she founded her own dance school where her students included [[Martha Graham]]. Craddock never established her own school and this is considered the reason that she never had the lasting impact that Ruth St. Denis made.<ref name=vam/> Deborah Jowitt writes that Craddock's dances may not have been learnt in India in fact she believes there is a lot of similarity between Craddock's style and that of St Denis some years before. St Denis however seemed to respect Craddock and she followed her career.<ref name="Jowitt1989"/>
Roshenara was captured by [[Ashcan School|Ashcan painter]] [[Robert Henri]]. The painting sold for $132,500 in 2000.<ref name=henri>[http://www.thecityreview.com/s00amps.htm American Paintings], ''The City Review'', Retrieved 14 October 2015</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Olive Katherine Craddock}} *[http://www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/person/mp55949/roshanara-olive-craddock Olive Craddock] at the [[National Portrait Gallery, London|National Portrait Gallery]]
{{Authority control}}
