revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=November 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2011}} {{Infobox Officeholder | name =Samuel Osaigbovo Ogbemudia | image = | imagesize = | smallimage = | caption = | order = | office =Governor, [[Mid-Western Region, Nigeria|Mid-West State]], Nigeria | term_start =26 October 1967 | term_end =July 1975 | predecessor =[[Albert Okonkwo]] | successor =[[George Innih]] | office2 =Governor, [[Bendel State]], Nigeria | term_start2 =October 1983 | term_end2 =31 December 1983 | predecessor2 =[[Ambrose Alli]] | successor2 =[[Jeremiah Timbut Useni]] | birth_date ={{Birth date|1932|9|17|df=y}} | birth_place = | death_date ={{death date and age|2017|3|9|1932|9|17|df=y}} | death_place = | nationality =[[Nigerian]] | spouse = | relations = | children = | residence = | alma_mater = | occupation = | profession = | religion = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Samuel Osaigbovo Ogbemudia''' (17 September 1932 – 9 March 2017)<ref name=nt>{{cite news|title=Dr Samuel Ogbemudia dies at 84: Nigerian reacts... – Tribune|url=http://tribuneonlineng.com/dr-samuel-ogbemudia-dies-84-nigerian-reacts/|accessdate=12 March 2017|work=Nigerian Tribune|date=11 March 2017}}</ref> was a Nigerian army officer and politician. He was military Governor (1967–1975) of the [[Mid-Western Region, Nigeria|Mid-West State]], later renamed [[Bendel State]], part of which in turn became [[Edo State]]. After the return to democracy in 1999, he became a power in the [[People's Democratic Party (Nigeria)|Peoples Democratic Party]] (PDP). In September 2009, Governor [[Adams Oshiomhole]] of Edo state and others attended his 77th birthday celebration in Benin.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2009/09/19/oshiomhole-uduaghan-fete-ogbemudia-at-70/comment-page-1/ |title=Oshiomhole, Uduaghan, fete Ogbemudia at 70 |date=19 September 2009 |author=Simon Ebegbulem |publisher=Vanguard |accessdate=27 November 2009}}</ref>
==Early years== Osaigbovo Ogbemudia was born in [[Benin City]] on September 17, 1932, he was named after his grandfather. In [[Edo language]], the name Ogbemudia can be inferred to mean "this family has come to stay".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Atuma|first1=Uche|title=Why I never wrote my memoirs|work=The Sun|date=March 12, 2017}}</ref> As a youth he lived with his elder cousin, Mr. FS Uwaifo, a Benin-based businessman.<ref>{{cite book |title=Elections 1983 |author=Mac Alabi |work=Daily Times |year=1983}}</ref> He attended Benin Baptist School (1941–1945), and then the government school, [[Limbe, Cameroon|Victoria]], in the [[Cameroons]] (1945–1947). His secondary education was at the Western Boy's High School, Benin City (1947–1949).<ref name=biof/>
He joined the Nigeria army in 1956, training at [[Teshie]], Ghana and at [[Netheravon]] and [[Salisbury Plain]] in England (1957). He attended the officer cadet school at [[Aldershot]], England in 1960, and was commissioned second lieutenant in 1961. He attended the United States army special welfare school at [[Fort Bragg (North Carolina)|Fort Bragg]], [[North Carolina]] in 1962. Ogbemudia served with the United Nations peacekeeping force in the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo|Congo]] for 16 months, and served in [[Tanzania]] in 1964. He was appointed as an instructor to the [[Nigerian Military School]], [[Zaria]] in 1964.<ref name=biof>{{cite web |url=http://www.edoworld.net/Ogbemudiabiography.html |title=Dr Osaigbovo Ogbemudia |author=Osamede Osunde |publisher=Edo World |accessdate=27 November 2009}}</ref>
==Career during military rule==
In January, 1966, a coup d'état overthrew the civilian government of Nigeria. In July 1966 the military ruler Major General [[Johnson Aguiyi-Ironsi]] was deposed and killed in the so-called [[Nigerian Counter-Coup of 1966]] led by Lieutenant Colonel [[Murtala Mohammed]]. Ironsi's chief of staff [[Yakubu Gowon]] became head of state. As the Brigade Major of the Ist Brigade in Kaduna,<ref>concord</ref> Ogbemudia played an important role in the counter-coup by disarming his troops in [[Kaduna]] at the suggestion of artillery commander Lt-Colonel Alex Madiebo.<ref name=oilpv>{{cite book |title=Oil, Politics and Violence: Nigeria's Military Coup Culture (1966–1976) |author=Max Siollun |publisher=Algora Publishing |year=2009 |ISBN=0-87586-708-1 |pages=113–114, 186}}</ref> During the counter-coup/mutiny, an attempt on Major Ogbemudia's life was also made by then Lt [[Buka Suka Dimka]] but Major Ogbemudia escaped because of a tip from Colonel [[Hassan Katsina]] and Major Abba Kyari.<ref name=Omoigui-Gamji>{{cite web|last1=Omoigui|first1=Nowa|title=Operation Aure (3)|url=http://www.gamji.com/nowa/nowa28.htm|website=Gamji|accessdate=16 January 2015}}</ref> In August that year he was transferred to the area command, Benin City as Quarter Master-General, 4th Area Command.<ref name="nowa">{{cite web|last1=Omogui|first1=Nowa|title=The Midwest Invasion of 1967: Lessons for Today's Geopolitics|url=http://www.dawodu.net/midwest.htm|website=dawodu.net}}</ref> Ogbemudia along with Major General Ejoor, the Military Governor of the Mid-western State and Pius Ermobor, an intelligence officer were the only three officers of the rank of Major and above who held strategic leaderships positions and who were not from the Igbo speaking communities of the Mid-west region.<ref name="nowa"/> On August 9, 1967, Biafran troops led by [[Victor Banjo]] invaded Mid-western region and its capital, Benin city with minimal resistance, a surprise attack which success was helped in part by an arrangement between Biafran leaders and some senior officers from the 4th Area Command.<ref name="nowa"/> Ejoor was able to escape to Lagos while Ogbemudia briefly went underground organizing a resistance movement composed of people disaffected by the invasion.<ref name="nowa"/> He later left for Army Headquarters, Lagos and joined the Murtala Mohammed led Second Infantry Division on a counterattacking mission to Midwest.<ref name="nowa"/> On September 20, 1967, troops led by Ogbemudia seized Benin city from Biafran forces.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Friendly|first1=Alfred|title=A city shows scars of the Nigerian war.|work=New York Times|date=September 26, 1967}}</ref>
Ogbemudia was appointed Military administrator of Mid-West state in September, 1967 following the liberation of state from the secessionist [[Biafra]]n forces.<ref name=biof/> Promoted to Lt. Colonel, Ogbemudia was appointed Military Governor of the state on 26 October 1967.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dawodu.com/omoeboh1.htm |title=Opening Speech delivered by Mr. Justice J Omo-Eboh at 9 am on Day 1 of the Mid-Western State of Nigeria Rebel Activities Tribunal of Inquiry |date=17 November 1967 |publisher=Dawodu |accessdate=27 November 2009}}</ref> A populist, dedicated to reconstruction after the war, he initiated improvements in the areas of sports, urban development, education, public transportation, housing and commerce.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.sunnewsonline.com/webpages/opinion/2008/nov/24/opinion-24-11-2008-001.htm |title = Power and the Comrade – Governor |author = Tunde Thompson |date = 24 November 2008 |work = Sun News |accessdate = 28 November 2009 }}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> He built the Ogbe sports stadium, now named the [[Samuel Ogbemudia Stadium]], and in August 1973 he commissioned the three-story National Museum in [[Benin City]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.sunnewsonline.com/webpages/features/travels/2009/sept/24/Travel-24-09-2009-001.htm |title = National Museu Benin demolitions: 'Assault on Nigeria’s heritage' |author = Maurice Archibong |date = 24 September 2009 |work = Sun News |accessdate = 28 November 2009 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100411091836/http://www.sunnewsonline.com/webpages/features/travels/2009/sept/24/Travel-24-09-2009-001.htm |archivedate = 11 April 2010 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> Other projects included the Agbede Mechanized Farm, Rural Electrification Board, Bendel Steel Structures, Bendel Pharmaceuticals, Bendel Boatyard, the [[University of Benin (Nigeria)|University of Benin]] and the Bendel Line.<ref name=biof/> In later years, people looked back on his governorship as a time when much was achieved, followed by stagnation in later administrations.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.sunnewsonline.com/webpages/features/citysun/2009/nov/11/citysun-11-11-2009-001.htm |title = Oshiomhole’s first-year scorecard ‘We’re rebuilding Edo from scratch’ |author = Tope Adeboboye |date = 11 November 2009 |work = Sun News |accessdate = 28 November 2009 }}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.sunnewsonline.com/webpages/politics/2009/nov/16/politics-16-11-2009-001.htm |title = My battle with Anenih, by Oshiomhole: PDP’s attraction is their rigging machine |author = CHIDI OBINECHE |date = 16 November 2009 |work = Sun News |accessdate = 28 November 2009 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091118020513/http://www.sunnewsonline.com/webpages/politics/2009/nov/16/politics-16-11-2009-001.htm |archivedate = 18 November 2009 |df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.sunnewsonline.com/webpages/politics/2009/sept/24/politics-24-09-2009-001.htm |title = Scavengers! ...Giwa-Amu slams politicians for serving themselves |author = Taiwo OLuwadare |date = 24 September 2009 |work = Sun News |accessdate = 28 November 2009 }}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Members of his cabinet included Edwin Clark, Frank Oputa-Otutu, [[T.E.A. Salubi]], and Lawrence Leo Borha.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Mbah|title=From the start to surrender the story and records of Nigerian Civil War for unity : including current affairs of the twelve states cabinet|date=1971|publisher=Appolos Bros Press|page=42|url=http://ufdc.ufl.edu/UF00023272/00001/43?search=clark}}</ref>
In July 1975, when [[Murtala Mohammed]] became head of state, he retired the twelve military governors who had served under [[Yakubu Gowon]]. The retirement of governors found guilty of corruption was converted to dismissal. Among these was Brigadier General Samuel Ogbemudia, whom Murtala, then leader of the Mid-west invasion had unilaterally appointed eight years earlier, and whom he replaced by Colonel [[George Agbazika Innih]]. Ogbemudia was investigated by a panel in 1975 but felt he could not receive a fair trial because the head of the panel had been relieved of his previous position by Ogbemudia. The 1975 asset investigation panel however found him guilt of corrupt enrichment. In the second republic, he was cleared by the Bendel State House of Assembly of mis-governance.
Ogbemudia was in London during the July 1975 coup and helped with renovations of Gowon's London abode after the ex-president went into exile.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Elaigwu|first1=Isawa|title=Gowon : The Biography of a Soldier-Statesman|date=2009|publisher=Adonis & Abbey Publishers Ltd|location=London|pages=334}}</ref>
==Post military career==
During a brief return to civil rule, Samuel Ogbemudia was elected governor of [[Bendel State]] in Oct 1983 as candidate for the [[National Party of Nigeria]], replacing [[Ambrose Alli]] of the [[Unity Party of Nigeria]]. However, he lost his position in December that year when [[Muhammadu Buhari]] became military ruler after a coup d'état that overthrew civilian President [[Shehu Shagari]].<ref name=nt/>
Between 1987 and 1989, Ogbemudia Chairman of the Nigerian Sports Commission, in 1989, Babangida appointed him as the Sole Administrator of the struggling [[Nigerian Railway Corporation]] (NRC). During his administration, the operations and finances of the corporation improved before he left NRC in 1992.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Odeleye|first1=Joshua|title=Public–Private Participation to Rescue Railway Development in Nigeria|url=http://www.jrtr.net/jrtr23/pdf/F42_Odeleye.pdf}}</ref>
General [[Sani Abacha]], military head of state from November, 1993 until his death in June, 1998, appointed Ogbemudia as minister for Labor and Productivity.<ref>{{cite book |title=Identity transformation and identity politics under structural adjustment in Nigeria |author=Attahiru Jega |publisher=Nordic Africa Institute |year=2000 |ISBN=91-7106-456-7 |page=223}}</ref> Samuel Ogbemudia was quoted as saying he would die for Abacha.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.thisdayonline.com/archive/2004/02/21/20040221pol03.html |title = Daniel Kanu's New Deal |author = Haruna Falalu |date = 21 February 2004 |publisher = ThisDay |accessdate = 28 November 2009 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091208015657/http://www.thisdayonline.com/archive/2004/02/21/20040221pol03.html |archivedate = 8 December 2009 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> Ogbemudia supported a move to have Abacha stand for election, saying "The nation has made wonderful progress under General Abacha ... He is, no doubt, the only answer to Nigeria's progress and development".<ref>{{cite book |title=Zones of conflict in Africa: theories and cases |author=George Klay Kieh, Ida Rousseau Mukenge |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |year=2002 |ISBN=0-275-97447-2 |page=116}}</ref>
===Fourth republic===
After the restoration of democracy in 1998/1999, Ogbemudia was one of the founders of the [[People's Democratic Party (Nigeria)|Peoples Democratic Party]] (PDP) in Edo state, and a member of the party's Board of Trustees.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2009/10/26/anenih-ogbemudia-ll-reconcile-says-sen-braimoh/ |title=Anenih, Ogbemudia'll reconcile, says Sen Braimoh |date=26 October 2009 |author=Emmanuel Aziken |publisher=Vanguard |accessdate=27 November 2009}}</ref> Ogbemudia and Chief [[Anthony Anenih]] between them controlled PDP politics in Edo State for the next decade, at first working well together but later coming into open conflict.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.news.dailytrust.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=7511:edo-pdp-reconciliation-how-far-will-it-go&catid=48:inside-politics&Itemid=123 |title = Edo PDP reconciliation: How far will it go? |author = Suleiman M. Bisalla & Vincent Egunyanga |date = 9 October 2009 |publisher = Daily Trust |accessdate = 27 November 2009 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
In December 2004, Ogbemudia was said to have agreed that Anthony Anenih should nominate his choice of governor for Edo State. He said he did not want a situation where one senatorial district in the state had a permanent hold on the position of governor.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.biafranigeriaworld.com/archive/2004/dec/15/056.html |title=Intrigues as 2007 guber race hots up in Edo |author=Benson Agwu |publisher=BNW News |accessdate=27 November 2009}}</ref> In November 2007, at an enlarged meeting of the PDP at the [[Samuel Ogbemudia Stadium]] in [[Benin City|Benin]], Ogbemudia spoke strongly against proposals by Anthony Anenih to change existing zoning arrangement of offices, then walked out of the meeting.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.sunnewsonline.com/webpages/features/powergame/2007/nov/18/powergame-18-11-2007-001.htm |title = Anenih, Ogbemudia rift deepens |author = Tony Osauzo |date = 18 November 2007 |work = Daily Sun |accessdate = 27 November 2009 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090625232353/http://www.sunnewsonline.com/webpages/features/powergame/2007/nov/18/powergame-18-11-2007-001.htm |archivedate = 25 June 2009 |df = dmy-all }}</ref>
In December 2006, Ogbemudia expressed support for the presidential bid of Dr [[Mohammed Buba Marwa]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.sunnewsonline.com/webpages/features/newsonthehour/2006/dec/11/newsbreak-11-12-2006-001.htm |title = 2007 presidency: Ogbemudia, Igbinedion endorse Marwa |work = Sun News |date = 11 December 2006 |accessdate = 28 November 2009 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070125052845/http://www.sunnewsonline.com/webpages/features/newsonthehour/2006/dec/11/newsbreak-11-12-2006-001.htm# |archive-date = 25 January 2007 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }}</ref>
On 20 March 2008, a tribunal nullified the election of [[Oserheimen Osunbor]] (PDP) as Edo State governor due to voting irregularities, and declared comrade [[Adams Oshiomhole]] of the [[Action Congress]] as the winner.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200803210605.html |title=Oserheimen vs Oshiomhole – AC Hails Judiciary Over Ruling |author=Emmanuel Aziken,Tony Edike and Leon Usigbe |date=21 March 2008 |publisher=Vanguard |accessdate=28 November 2009}}</ref> In an interview in November that year, as a prominent member of the PDP board of trustees Ogbemudia said he would have preferred a PDP member to have won. However, he accepted the tribunal result, and described Oshiomhole as a man of strong character. He spoke critically of earlier governors, such as Chief [[Lucky Igbinedion]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.sunnewsonline.com/webpages/news/national/2008/nov/16/national-16-11-2008-011.htm |title = Ogbemudia to Oshiomhole: I’m ready to serve • Says ‘Appeal court judgment a shocker’ |author = Tony Osauzo |date = 16 November 2008 |work = Daily Sun |accessdate = 28 November 2009 }}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
In July 2009, Ogbemudia was leader of a PDP faction that was supporting Prof. [[Julius Ihonvbere]] as candidate for the Edo State governorship in 2011. A rival faction led by Tony Anenih favoured Senator [[Odion Ugbesia]] as candidate.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.sunnewsonline.com/webpages/features/powergame/2009/july/12/powergame-12-07-2009-001.htm |title = South South 2011: The storm gathers |date = 12 July 2009 |author = Tony Osauzo |work = Daily Sun |accessdate = 28 November 2009 }}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> In October 2009, Ogbemudia failed to attend the unity rally of the party in Edo state organised by Anthony Anenih.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200910260107.html |title=Ogbemudia Shuns Anenih's Group Rally |author=Akeem Oguntayo |date=25 October 2009 |publisher=Daily Champion |accessdate=27 November 2009}}</ref> A month later, Ogbemudia praised Oshiomhole's accomplishments in his first year of office, leading to speculations of a possible political alliance between the two men.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.sunnewsonline.com/webpages/news/national/2009/nov/13/national-13-11-2009-00-001.htm |title = Don't vote without electoral reform |author = Louis Iba |date = 13 November 2009 |work = Daily Sun |accessdate = 28 November 2009 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091116021247/http://www.sunnewsonline.com/webpages/news/national/2009/nov/13/national-13-11-2009-00-001.htm |archivedate = 16 November 2009 |df = dmy-all }}</ref>

{{about||the United States Navy ship|USS Tasco (SP-502)|the Colombian municipality|Tasco, Boyacá}}
{{Infobox company | logo = <!-- Commented out because image was deleted: [[Image:TascoLogo.jpg]] --> | type = [[Corporation]] | foundation = 1954 | founder = George Rosenfield | location_city = [[Miami, FL]] | location_country = United States | industry = [[Technology]] | homepage = {{URL|http://www.tasco.com}} }}
'''Tasco''' (also known as '''Tasco Worldwide''') is a major distributor of consumer [[telescope]]s worldwide. Tasco mainly makes telescopes for amateur [[astronomy|astronomers]] but has expanded into other [[optical]] products such as [[spotting scope]]s, [[microscopes]], binoculars, and [[telescopic sight]]s and other rifle accessories. Tasco sells via specialty outlets, [[Mail order|catalogues]], and online retailers.
Tasco is based in [[Miramar, Florida]]. George Rosenfield founded the firm as the '''Tanross Supply Company''' in 1954. It started as a distributor of [[fishing tackle]] and hardware. The name was later shortened to Tasco as inventory expanded to include [[binoculars]] and eyepieces.<ref name="accessed Sept 17, 2007">http://www.company7.com/celestron/news/tasco.html accessed Sept 17, 2007.</ref>
==Products== Tasco manufactures a variety of optical equipment including terrestrial telescopes, microscopes, binoculars, telescopic sights, and accessories.
===Telescopes=== [[Image:Tasco SkyWatcher Telescopes.jpg|thumb|150px|Department store 50 mm Tasco Specialty Refractor on modified mount (lower left) and a 114mm [[Sky-Watcher]] reflector.]] Three categories of telescopes are available from Tasco - ''Novice,'' ''Luminova'', and ''Spacestation.'' Each family has several models. The ''Novice'' family features the most [[economical]] telescopes using manual focus and view finding, while the high end ''Spacestation'' utilizes fully [[automated]] sky-mapping, "[[GoTo (telescopes)|GoTo]]" technology. [[Magnification]] ranges of the telescopes are advertised as between 25 and 675 power.<ref>As the focal length of the telescope divided by that of the eyepiece determines magnification; advertised magnification is irrelevant.</ref>
Tasco's astronomical telescopes have a noted poor reputation as a usable instrument.<ref name="Philip S. Harrington 2011, page 80">Philip S. Harrington, Star Ware: The Amateur Astronomer's Guide to Choosing, Buying, and Using Telescopes and Accessories, John Wiley & Sons - 2011, page 80</ref><ref>[http://uncle-rods.blogspot.com/2008/07/good-tasco.html Rod Mollise, The Good Tasco, Uncle Rod's Astro Blog. Sunday, July 13, 2008]</ref> It is one of several companies that follows the deceptive practice of advertising their products based on claims of high magnification, far beyond any attainable [[magnification#Maximum usable magnification|usable magnification]].<ref name="Philip S. Harrington 2011, page 80"/> Tasco's astronomical products usually get lumped in with the whole series of telescopes pejoratively referred to as "department store telescopes," low quality and low-cost instruments targeted at the [[impulse purchase]] market.<ref name="Philip S. Harrington 2011, page 80"/><ref>Michael Borgia, Human Vision and The Night Sky: How to Improve Your Observing Skills, Springer Science & Business Media - 2006, page 1</ref><ref>NIGHTWATCH: A Practical Guide to Viewing the Universe, [[Terence Dickinson]], {{ISBN|1-55209-302-6}} , Third Edition, pg 65: "Trash-Scope Blues"</ref>
==Company history==
Tasco was founded and owned by George Rosenfield in 1954. In March 1996, Rosenfield sold the business. At that time, Tasco employed 160 people at its [[Florida]] headquarters, and maintained a location in the state of [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]], which employed 40.<ref name="accessed Sept 17, 2007"/> In June 1998, Tasco purchased [[Celestron]], another telescope manufacturer which focused on [[performance]] optical equipment and the more serious observer. Celestron was second only to [[Meade Instruments|Meade Instruments Corporation]] in sales of telescopes.<ref name="accessed Sept 15, 2007">{{cite web |url=http://www.ftc.gov/opa/2002/05/meadecelestron.shtm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-09-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071023070334/http://www.ftc.gov/opa/2002/05/meadecelestron.shtm |archivedate=2007-10-23 |df= }} accessed Sept 15, 2007</ref>
Early 2001, Tasco began searching for a buyer as profits sank. Meade Corporation begins negotiations for a [[merger]], but the [[Federal Trade Commission]] blocked the attempt.
By June 2002, [[Wind Point Partners]], the parent company of [[Bushnell Corporation|Bushnell Performance Optics]] (BPO) purchased the Tasco brand and all the company's [[intellectual property]].
In July 2007, Wind Point Partners sold [[Bushnell Corporation|Bushnell Performance Optics]] along with Tasco property and sales rights to [[MidOcean Partners]], a [[private equity]] firm based in [[New York City|New York]] and [[London]].<ref>[http://marketing.bushnell.com/press/pdf/Bushnell%20Acquisition.pdf MidOcean Partners and Management Announce Acquisition Of Bushnell Outdoor Products, Inc. from Wind Point Partners] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071111010633/http://marketing.bushnell.com/press/pdf/Bushnell%20Acquisition.pdf |date=2007-11-11 }}</ref>
On Sept. 5, 2013, [[Alliant Techsystems]] announced it had entered into a definitive agreement to acquire Bushnell. Under the terms of the transaction, ATK paid $985 million in cash, subject to customary post-closing adjustments.<ref>[http://atk.mediaroom.com/2013-11-04-ATK-Completes-Acquisition-of-Bushnell-Group-Holdings-Inc ATK Completes Acquisition of Bushnell Group Holdings, Inc] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104182251/http://atk.mediaroom.com/2013-11-04-ATK-Completes-Acquisition-of-Bushnell-Group-Holdings-Inc |date=November 4, 2013 }}</ref>
ATK spun-off Vista Outdoor upon closing its merger with [[Orbital Sciences]] and became [[Orbital ATK]] on February 9, 2015. Anyone holding ATK common stock at the end of the business day on February 2, 2015 received two shares of Vista Outdoor common stock. Eligible shareholders had their brokerage account credited or received a book-entry account statement reflecting their ownership. Vista Outdoor was thus initially 100% owned by ATK shareholders. Vista Outdoor stock traded on a "when-issued" basis from January 29, 2015 to February 9, 2015. It began "regular way" trading on the [[New York Stock Exchange]] on February 10, 2015 under the ticker symbol "VSTO." No payment or action of any kind was required of shareholders. This transaction was conducted on a tax-free basis. U.S. shareholders generally did not have to recognize a gain or loss for federal tax purposes.<ref name="Washington1">{{cite news |last=Clabaugh |first=Jeff |date=9 February 2015 |title=Orbital, ATK complete aerospace merger |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/washington/blog/fedbiz_daily/2015/02/orbital-atk-complete-aerospace-merger.html |newspaper=Washington Business Journal |access-date=10 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="Star1">{{cite news |last=Depass |first=Dee Dee |date=9 February 2015 |title=Alliant spinoff, merger completed |newspaper=StarTribune |location=Minneapolis, Minnesota }}</ref><ref name="247WS">{{cite news |last=Lee |first=Jackson |date=13 January 2015 |title=3 Top Defense Stocks That May Benefit From New Congress |url=http://247wallst.com/aerospace-defense/2015/01/12/3-top-defense-stocks-that-may-benefit-from-new-congress/ |newspaper=24/7 Wall St. |location=New York, New York |access-date=10 February 2015}}</ref>
==Litigation== On May 29, 2002, Tasco Worldwide initiated [[liquidation]] of all its [[assets]].<ref>''Miramar, Fla.-Based Binocular, Telescope Distributor Starts to Liquidate''. The Miami Herald (FL), May 29, 2002.</ref> after defaulting on nearly $30 million in loans.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Di Cicco|first1=Dennis|title=Celestron, Tasco Out of Business?|journal=Sky & Telescope|date=23 July 2003 |url=http://www.skyandtelescope.com/news/3306111.html?page=1&c=y |accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref> The company had been searching for a buyer for several months, but after much interest by Meade Corporation, the Federal Trade Commission, on this day, sanctioned a temporary [[restraining order]] in [[federal district court]] to preempt any attempt by Meade Instruments Corporation, the leading manufacturer of performance telescopes in the United States, to purchase all, or certain assets, of Tasco Holdings, Inc. including Celestron, a child-company, and number two performance telescope provider in the U.S. The FTC argued that an acquisition by Meade of Celestron would negatively impact the performance telescope market by eliminating significant [[competition]] between the two companies and by creating a [[monopoly]] in the market for [[Schmidt-Cassegrain]] telescopes, which were currently only being sold in the U.S. by Celestron and Meade.<ref name="accessed Sept 15, 2007"/>
Later in 2002, Tasco and Celestron, then under the ownership of [[Bushnell Corporation|Bushnell Performance Optics]], fired back with lawsuits also in the District Court of California, alleging Meade products infringed on a United States patent entitled "Tripod Structure for Telescopes." Both companies sought [[injunctive relief]] and [[compensatory damages]] in an unspecified amount, and attorneys' fees and costs. In December 2002, the District Court denied both Celestron's and Tasco’s motion.<ref name="MEADE-INSTRUMENTS-CORP-May-2003-10-K">{{cite web|url=http://edgar.secdatabase.com/162/89256903001421/filing-main.htm |title=MEADE INSTRUMENTS CORP, Form 10-K, Annual Report, Filing Date May 29, 2003 |publisher=secdatabase.com |accessdate =May 14, 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Teddy Pilley | image = | image_size = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1909|03|07|df=yes}} | birth_place = Paris, France | death_date = {{Death-date and age|June 1982|March 1909}} | death_place = London, England }}
'''Teddy (Thadée) Pilley''' was a [[Language interpretation|linguist and conference interpreter]].
==Family== He was born as '''Ari Thaddeus Pilichowski''' in [[Paris]]. His parents, [[Leopold Pilichowski]] (1860{{ndash}}1934) and Lena Pillico (Pilichowski) (1884{{ndash}}1947),<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.geni.com/people/Lena-Pilichowski/5117702033880129336 |title=Genealogy: Lena Pilichowski (Pillico) |access-date=2016-10-28}}</ref> were Jewish [[émigrés]] from Poland and were both accomplished artists. Pilley had two sisters, Maia Gainsborough (Pilichowski) (1904{{ndash}}1936) and Thea Doniach (Pilichowski) (1907{{ndash}}1986), and a brother Vivien Pilley (Pilichowski) (1907{{ndash}}1982). When Teddy Pilley was 4‑years old, his parents moved the family from Paris to [[London]], where he remained until his death.
He was married to Nora (Sachs), and they had one son, Peter.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.geni.com/people/Norah-Pilley/6000000003730040229 |title=Genealogy: Nora Pilley |access-date=2016-10-28}}</ref>
==Education== Pilley's early education was at [[Merchant Taylors' School, Northwood|Merchant Taylors' School]] in London. He then studied at [[St John's College, Oxford]], graduating with a [[Philosophy, Politics and Economics|PPE]] degree.{{citation needed|date=February 2015}}
==Second World War== During the [[Second World War]], Pilley served in the [[Royal Air Force|RAF]], reaching the rank of [[Squadron leader]]. Pilley was first stationed at [[RAF Aldergrove]] in [[Northern Ireland]], where he flew with [[No. 245 Squadron RAF|No.245 Squadron]].
He was later transferred to [[Bletchley Park]], where he remained for the duration of the war.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://rollofhonour.bletchleypark.org.uk/search/record-detail/7266/ |title=Bletchley Park: Roll of Honour |access-date=2016-10-28}}</ref><ref name=Sugarman>{{cite web |url=http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/ww2/bletchleyjews.html# |title=Jewish Personnel at Bletchley Park in World War Two |series=Jewish Virtual Library |last=Sugarman |first=Martin |access-date=2016-10-28}}</ref> At Bletchley, he worked in the Air Intelligence section in [[Hut 3]], translating, classifying and prioritizing [[Luftwaffe]] signals, which had previously been intercepted and then decoded using [[Bombe]] and [[Cryptanalysis of the Enigma|Enigma]] machines.
==Conference interpreting== During the post-war years, Pilley became a renowned linguist and conference interpreter. He interpreted principally between French (his [[First language|mother tongue]]) and English, and vice versa; in addition, he was competent in both German and Dutch, and could also converse in several other European languages.
Pilley was well known as an organizer and recruiter of simultaneous-interpreting teams for major international conferences worldwide, operating as the ''International Conference Secretariat''.<ref name=Keiser>{{cite web |url=http://www.erudit.org/revue/meta/2004/v/n3/009380ar.html |last=Keiser |first=Walter |date=2004 |title=L'interprétation de conférence en tant que profession et les précurseurs de l'Association Internationale des Interprètes de Conférence (AIIC) 1918-1953 |trans-title=Conference interpreting as a profession and the precursors of the International Association of Conference Interpreters (AIIC) 1918-1953 |website=Érudit |series=Meta: Translators' Journal v.49, n.3 |pages=576-608 |language= French |access-date=2016-10-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |url=http://aiic.net/page/1169/extrait-de-tous-les-fleuves-vont-a-la-mer/lang/2 |last=Wiesel |first=Elie |date=1994 |title=Tous les fleuves vont à la mer |trans-title=All rivers lead to the sea |website=AIIC |series=Editions du Seuil |language=French |access-date=2014-10-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Widlund-Fantini |first=Anne-Marie |date=2007 |title=''Danica Seleskovitch: Interprète et témoin du XXe siècle'' |trans-title=Danica Seleskovitch: Interpreter and witness to the 20th century |language=French |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=ZuZ3bllaUc8C&pg=PA244&dq=isbn+978-2-8251-3697-3&hl=en&ei=osJNTe-yC4iqsAO3s8GmCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDYQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=pilley&f=false |location=Lausanne |publisher=L'Age d'Homme |isbn=978-2-8251-3697-3 |access-date=2016-10-28}}</ref><ref name=Bootheando>{{cite web |url=http://www.bootheando.com/2013/03/08/la-historia-de-la-interpretacion-simultanea-de-la-mano-de-ted-pilley |date=2013 |title=La historia de la interpretación simultánea de la mano de Ted Pilley |trans-title=Simultaneous interpreting, as practiced by Ted Pilley |language=Spanish |website= Bootheando |series=Historia, Interpretación, Interpretación simultánea, Intérprete |access-date=2016-10-28}}</ref> In the 1950s, before conference venues had proper facilities for interpreters, Pilley developed portable equipment, consisting of microphones, headphones, wiring and associated electronics; this equipment could be moved from place to place, to provide temporary facilities for simultaneous interpreting during international conferences; Pilley named this equipment [[Archie Andrews (puppet)|''Archie'']], after the famous ventriloquist’s dummy.<ref name=Keiser/>
Pilley was a co-founder of the [[International Association of Conference Interpreters]], and of the [[Institute of Linguists]]. He was also the owner and principal of [[Linguists' Club (London)|The Linguists’ Club]],<ref>{{cite journal |last=Finney |first=Elizabeth |date=November 2016 |title=Welcome to The Club |url=https://issuu.com/runwildmedia/docs/k_c_nov_16 |journal=Kensington & Chelsea Magazine |issue=057 |pages=48–49 |access-date=2016-10-26}}</ref> a language and social club in London. At The Linguists’ Club, Pilley established ''working parties'', an educational tool used to teach aspiring interpreters. Participants were first screened to establish both their language proficiency as well as their aptitude to the work; successful applicants were then trained in the art of professional interpreting.<ref name=Keiser/><ref name=Bootheando/>
In his later years, Pilley was recognized as an [[Ordre des Palmes Académiques|''Officier d’Académie'']] by the French Government, for his services to France.<ref name=Sugarman/>
==References== {{reflist|2}}

'''Thomas Barnacle''' (1846 – 9 July 1921<ref>https://civilrecords.irishgenealogy.ie/churchrecords/details-civil/69cc119631663?b=https%3A%2F%2Fcivilrecords.irishgenealogy.ie%2Fchurchrecords%2Fcivil-perform-search.jsp%3Fnamefm%3DThomas%26namel%3DBarnacle%26exact%3D%26name2fm%3D%26name2l%3D%26location%3D%26yyfrom%3D1921%26yyto%3D%26type%3DD%26century%3D%26decade%3D%26sort%3D%26pageSize%3D100%26ddBfrom%3D%26mmBfrom%3D%26yyBfrom%3D%26ddMfrom%3D%26mmMfrom%3D%26yyMfrom%3D%26ddDfrom%3D%26mmDfrom%3D%26yyDfrom%3D%26ddPfrom%3D%26mmPfrom%3D%26yyPfrom%3D%26ddBto%3D%26mmBto%3D%26yyBto%3D%26ddMto%3D%26mmMto%3D%26yyMto%3D%26ddDto%3D%26mmDto%3D%26yyDto%3D%26ddPto%3D%26mmPto%3D%26yyPto%3D%26locationB%3D%26locationM%3D%26locationD%3D%26locationP%3D%26keywordb%3D%26keywordm%3D%26keywordd%3D%26keywordp%3D%26event%3D%26district%3DGalway%26submit%3DSearch</ref>) from [[Galway]], Ireland was the father of [[Nora Barnacle]] and father-in-law of the novelist, [[James Joyce]].
Barnacle was active in the [[trade unions]] from the 1860s to the 1890s. Though [[illiterate]], he had a trade as a well-skilled [[baker]]—the family line of work—and was much in demand till the end of his life. He often freelanced beyond the town in such places as [[Oughterard]].
He married Annie Honoria Healy in 1881 and they had children Mary, Nora, Bridget (known as Delia), Thomas, and Kathleen (born 1896). One other boy died in infancy, and two other daughters are known to have been born to the couple.
Thomas and Annie moved house some seven times by 1904, all in lowly working-class districts of Galway such as Newtownsmyth, Raleigh Row, and Abbeygate Street, before eventually settling at number 8 (now number 4) Bowling Green, an L-shaped street below the church of [[St. Nicholas]].
Sometime around 1896, Annie threw Thomas out of the house due to his severe drinking which had led to the loss of his bakery shop. However, he remained in demand as a [[journeyman]] baker.
While his son-in-law [[James Joyce]] (who never met him) depicted him as rough, irresponsible man, Thomas himself was very well liked by all who knew him, and was remembered very fondly by his daughter Nora. Many years later, Nora wrote to her sister Kathleen, of Joyce: ''"He's a weakling, Kathleen. I always have to be after his tail. I wish I was married to a man like my father."'' Nora Barnacle's Galway [[biographer]], Padriag Ó Laoi noted him as a genial man of five foot nine, good humored and an excellent storyteller and stated that ''"True, he took a drink, but he never disgraced his family".''
Barnacle died in 1921, having been nursed during his illness by his estranged wife, Annie.
==References== {{Reflist}} * ''Nora:A Biography of Nora Joyce'', [[Brenda Maddox]], [[London]], 1988. {{ISBN|0-7493-9014-X}}
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Barnacle, Thomas}} [[Category:1846 births]] [[Category:1921 deaths]] [[Category:People associated with James Joyce]] [[Category:People from County Galway]]
{{Ireland-bio-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} [[File:MaryWollstonecraft.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Half-length portrait of a woman leaning on a desk with a book and an inkstand. She is wearing a blue-striped dress and a gray, curly wig crossed by a white band of cloth.|[[Mary Wollstonecraft]] by [[John Opie]] (c. 1791)]]
{{Use British English|date=May 2013}} The lifetime of [[Kingdom of Great Britain|British]] writer, [[Philosophy|philosopher]], and [[Feminism|feminist]] [[Mary Wollstonecraft]] (1759–1797) encompassed most of the second half of the eighteenth century, a time of great political and social upheaval throughout Europe and America: political [[Radicalism (historical)#United Kingdom|reform movements]] in Britain gained strength, the [[American revolution|American colonists successfully rebelled]], and the [[French revolution]] erupted. Wollstonecraft experienced only the headiest of these days, not living to see the end of the democratic revolution when [[Napoleon]] crowned himself emperor. Although Britain was still revelling in its mid-century imperial conquests and its triumph in the [[Seven Years' War]], it was the French revolution that defined Wollstonecraft's generation. As poet [[Robert Southey]] later wrote: "few persons but those who have lived in it can conceive or comprehend what the memory of the French Revolution was, nor what a visionary world seemed to open upon those who were just entering it. Old things seemed passing away, and nothing was dreamt of but the regeneration of the human race."<ref>Southey, Robert. [http://www.wwnorton.com/college/english/nael/romantic/topic_3/welcome.htm The Correspondence of Robert Southey with Caroline Bowles, ed. Edward Dowden]. ''Norton Anthology of English Literature: Norton Topics Online''. Retrieved 27 August 2007.</ref>
Part of what made reform possible in Britain in the second half of the eighteenth century was the dramatic increase in publishing; books, periodicals, and pamphlets became much more widely available than they had been just a few decades earlier.<ref>Kelly, Gary. ''English Fiction of the Romantic Period, 1789–1830''. London: Longman (1989), 2.</ref> This increase in available printed material helped facilitate the rise of the British middle class. Reacting against what they viewed as aristocratic decadence, the new professional middle classes (made prosperous through British manufacturing and trade), offered their own ethical code: reason, meritocracy, self-reliance, religious toleration, free inquiry, free enterprise, and hard work.<ref>Kelly, 10.</ref> They set these values against what they perceived as the superstition and unreason of the poor and the prejudices, censorship, and self-indulgence of the rich. They also helped establish what has come to be called the "cult of domesticity", which solidified gender roles for men and women.<ref>Kelly, 10-11.</ref> This new vision of society rested on the writings of [[Scottish Enlightenment]] philosophers such as [[Adam Smith]], who had developed a theory of social progress founded on sympathy and [[sensibility]]. A partial critique of the rationalist Enlightenment, these theories promoted a combination of reason and feeling that enabled women to enter the public sphere because of their keen moral sense.<ref>Kelly, 13.</ref> Wollstonecraft's writings stand at the nexus of all of these changes. Her educational works, such as her [[children's literature|children's book]] ''[[Original Stories from Real Life]]'' (1788), helped inculcate middle-class values, and her two ''Vindications'', ''[[A Vindication of the Rights of Men]]'' (1790) and ''[[A Vindication of the Rights of Woman]]'' (1792), argue for the value of an educated, rational populace, specifically one that includes women. In her two novels, ''[[Mary: A Fiction]]'' and ''[[Maria: or, The Wrongs of Woman]]'', she explores the ramifications of sensibility for women.
The end of the eighteenth century was a time of great hope for progressive reformers such as Wollstonecraft. Like the revolutionary pamphleteer [[Thomas Paine]] and others, Wollstonecraft was not content to remain on the sidelines. She sought out intellectual debate at the home of her publisher [[Joseph Johnson (publisher)|Joseph Johnson]], who gathered leading thinkers and artists for weekly dinners,<ref>[[Todd, Janet]]. ''Mary Wollstonecraft: A Revolutionary Life''. London: Weidenfeld & Nicolson (2000), 152-53</ref> and she traveled extensively, first to be a part of the French revolution and later to seek a lost treasure ship for her lover in what was then exotic Scandinavia, turning her journey into a [[travel literature|travel book]], ''[[Letters Written in Sweden, Norway, and Denmark]]''. After two complicated and heart-rending affairs with the artist [[Henry Fuseli]] and the American adventurer [[Gilbert Imlay]] (with whom she had an [[illegitimacy|illegitimate]] daughter, [[Fanny Imlay]]), Wollstonecraft married the philosopher [[William Godwin]], one of the forefathers of the [[anarchist]] movement.<ref>Todd, 417ff.</ref> Together, they had one daughter: [[Mary Shelley]], the author of ''[[Frankenstein]]''. Wollstonecraft died at the age of 38 due to complications from this birth, leaving behind several unfinished manuscripts.<ref>Todd, 452ff.</ref> Today, she is most often remembered for her political treatise ''[[A Vindication of the Rights of Woman]]'' and is considered a foundational [[feminist philosophy|feminist philosopher]].<ref>Kaplan, Cora. "Mary Wollstonecraft's reception and legacies". ''The Cambridge Companion to Mary Wollstonecraft''. Ed. Claudia L. Johnson. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press (2002).</ref> {{clear}} <!--Please do not add any information to this chronology unless you cite a reliable source (see [[WP:V]]) using an inline citation (see [[WP:CITE]]) -- Thanks-->
==Timeline==
===1750s=== {| class="wikitable" |-

!Year !width=31%|Wollstonecraft !width=31%|Literature !width=31%|History |- | '''1760''' | | * June – [[James Macpherson]] allegedly translates, but himself actually writes, poems by [[Ossian]]; published as ''[[Fragments of Ancient Poetry collected in the Highlands of Scotland]]''<ref name=RC>{{cite web|author=Mandell, Laura|author2=Alan Liu |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720073931/http://english.ucsb.edu:591/rchrono/default.htm|title=Romantic Chronology|url=http://english.ucsb.edu:591/rchrono/default.htm|archivedate=20 July 2011|date=5 August 2007}}</ref> * Publication of the first volume of [[Laurence Sterne]]'s novel ''[[Tristram Shandy]]'' (1760–1767)<ref name=Norton/> | [[File:Allan Ramsay - King George III in coronation robes - Google Art Project.jpg|right|100x100px|alt=Man dressed in elaborate gold, white, and black coronation robes made of satin and fur.]] * April – [[Tacky's War|Tacky's Slave Revolt]] in [[Jamaica]]<ref name=BBC/> * 25 October – [[George III of the United Kingdom|George III]] (''pictured'') ascends to the throne of [[Kingdom of Britain|Britain]]<ref name=Norton/><ref name=BBC/> |- | '''1761''' | * Birth of Henry Woodstock Wollstonecraft (brother to Mary)<ref name=MandS/> | * Publication of [[Jean-Jacques Rousseau]]'s novel ''[[Julie, or the New Heloise]]''<ref name=Lynch/> | |- | '''1762'''
| | [[File:EmileTitle.jpeg|right|100x100px|alt=Title page reads "Émile, ou de L'Education. Par J. J. Rousseau, Citoyen de Genève....Tome Premier. A La Haye, Chez jean Neaulme, Libraire. journalist [[John Wilkes]] is arrested for criticizing George III<ref name=BBC/> |- | '''1765''' | * Birth of Everina (Averina) Wollstonecraft (sister to Mary)<ref name=MandS/> * The Wollstonecraft family moves to [[Barking, London|Barking]]<ref name=Taylor/> | * Publication of [[Samuel Johnson|Johnson's]] collected works of [[Shakespeare's reputation#18th century|Shakespeare]]<ref name=Norton/> * Publication of [[Horace Walpole]]'s ''[[The Castle of Otranto]]'', widely considered the first [[Gothic novel]]<ref name=Lynch/> * Publication of [[William Blackstone]]'s treatise ''[[Commentaries on the Laws of England]]''<ref name=RC/> | * March – [[American Revolution#1765: Stamp Act unites the Colonies in protest|Riots erupt in American colonies]] after the British parliament levies the [[Oliver Goldsmith]]'s novel ''[[The Vicar of Wakefield]]''<ref name=RC/> | |- | '''1768''' | * Birth of James Wollstonecraft (brother to Mary)<ref name=MandS/> * October – The Wollstonecraft family moves to [[Beverley]], [[Yorkshire]]<ref name=Taylor/><ref>Todd, 8.</ref> * Wollstonecraft meets [[Jane Gardiner|Jane Arden]], her first intimate friend<ref name=Taylor/> | [[File:Angelica Kauffmann 002.png|right|100x100px|alt=A charitable couple giving money to a poor monk.]] * Publication of [[Laurence Sterne]]'s novel ''[[A Sentimental Journey through France and Italy]]''<ref name=Lynch/> | * ===1770s===
{| class="wikitable" |-
!Year !width=31%|Wollstonecraft !width=31%|Literature !width=31%|History |- | '''1770''' | * Birth of Charles Wollstonecraft (brother to Mary)<ref name=MandS/> | * Publication of [[Oliver Goldsmith|Goldsmith's]] poem ''[[The Deserted Village]]''<ref name=Norton/> * Publication of Part I of [[Goethe]]'s play ''[[Goethe's Faust|Faust]]''<ref name=Lynch/> | * January – [[Frederick, Lord North]] becomes [[Prime Minister of Great Britain]] (1770–1782)<ref name=BBC/> |- | '''1771''' | | * Publication of the first edition of the ''[[Encyclopædia Britannica]]''<ref name=Lynch/> | * [[Richard Arkwright]] opens the first [[cotton mill]] in [[Cromford]], [[Derbyshire]], England<ref name=BBC/> |- | '''1772''' | | * December – Publication of [[Anna Laetitia Barbauld]]'s ''Poems''<ref name=RC/> * December – Publication of ''Miscellaneous Pieces in Prose'' by Barbauld and her brother, [[John Aikin]]<ref name=RC/> | * 22 June – [[Slavery]] is [[Somersett's Case|effectively outlawed]] in England<ref name=BBC/> |- | '''1773''' | | | * 16 December – American colonists protest British policies by [[Boston Tea Party|dumping tea into Boston Harbor]]<ref name=BBC/> |- | '''1774''' | * The Wollstonecraft family moves to [[Hoxton]]<ref name=CC/> * Wollstonecraft meets Mr. and Mrs. Clare, who provide a second home for her and educate her<ref name=CC/> * Through the Clares, Wollstonecraft first meets Fanny Blood, for whom she will develop deep feelings<ref name=CC/> | * Publication of [[Goethe]]'s novel ''[[The Sorrows of Young Werther]]''<ref name=Lynch/> | [[File:Louis16-1775.jpg|right|100x100px|alt=Half-length portrait of a man with a short gray wig and curls over both ears. His cream-colored jacket is decorated with medals and a light blue sash.]] * May – [[Louis XVI]] (''pictured'') ascends to the throne of France<ref name=Lynch/> * [[Warren Hastings]] becomes the first [[Governor-General of India]]<ref name=RC/> |- | '''1775''' | | | * 18 April – The [[American Revolution]] (1775–1783) begins with the [[Battles of Lexington and Concord|Battle of Lexington]]<ref name=Norton/><ref name=BBC/> * [[James Watt]] invents the [[steam engine]]<ref name=Norton/> |- | '''1776''' | * The Wollstonecraft family moves to [[Laugharne]], Wales<ref name=CC/> | * Publication of [[Adam Smith]]'s treatise ''[[Wealth of Nations]]''<ref name=Norton/> * Publication of the first volume of [[Edward Gibbon]]'s ''[[The History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire]]'' (1776–1788)<ref name=Lynch/> | |- | '''1777''' | * The Wollstonecraft family moves to [[Walworth, London]]<ref name=CC/> | * [[Richard Brinsley Sheridan]]'s play ''[[The School for Scandal]]'' opens at [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane|Drury Lane Theatre]]<ref name=Lynch/> | |- | '''1778''' | * Wollstonecraft's first job – [[lady's companion|paid companion]] to Mrs. Sarah Dawson in [[Windsor, Berkshire|Windsor]] and [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]]<ref name=MandS/> | [[File:ChapmanBarbauld.jpg|right|100px|alt=Half-length profile portrait of a woman wearing a bonnet]] * Publication of [[Frances Burney]]'s novel ''[[Evelina]]''<ref name=Norton/> * Publication of [[Anna Laetitia Barbauld|Barbauld's]] (''pictured'') reading primer ''[[Lessons for Children]]''<ref name=Lynch/> | |- | '''1779''' | | * Publication of [[Samuel Johnson|Johnson's]] ''[[Lives of the Poets]]'' (1779–1781)<ref name=Norton/> | |}
===1780s===
{| class="wikitable" |-
!Year !width=31%|Wollstonecraft !width=31%|Literature !width=31%|History |- | '''1780''' | * Wollstonecraft's parents and younger siblings move to [[Enfield Town|Enfield]]<ref name=Taylor/> | | * 2–11 June – [[Gordon Riots]] in London, protesting the [[Papists Act 1778|Catholic Relief Act]]<ref name=Norton/><ref name=BBC/> * [[John Cartwright (political reformer)|Major John Cartwright]] founds the radical [[Society for Constitutional Information]]<ref name=Lynch/> |- | '''1781''' | * Autumn – Wollstonecraft returns home to nurse her ill mother<ref name=CC/><ref>Todd, 39.</ref> | * Publication of [[Anna Laetitia Barbauld|Barbauld's]] ''[[Hymns in Prose for Children]]''<ref name=Lynch/> | * 19 October – French and American forces defeat the British at the [[Siege of Yorktown|Battle of Yorktown]], effectively ending the [[American War of Independence]]<ref name=BBC/> |- | '''1782''' | * 19 April – Wollstonecraft's mother dies<ref name=MandS/> * Wollstonecraft's father remarries and moves to Wales<ref name=CC/> * Wollstonecraft moves to [[Walham Green]] to live with Fanny Blood and her family<ref name=CC/> * 20 October – Eliza, Wollstonecraft's sister, marries Meredith Bishop<ref name=CC/><ref>Todd, 43.</ref> | [[File:Frances d'Arblay ('Fanny Burney') by Edward Francisco Burney.jpg|right|100x100px|alt=Half-length portrait of a woman looking left and away from the viewer. The painting is done in a palette of browns. Her hat, with its elaborate bow, dominates the top third of the painting. She is wearing a cream-colored dress with a rose-colored bow on the front of the bosom.]] * Publication of [[Frances Burney|Burney's]] (''pictured'') novel ''[[Cecilia (Burney novel)|Cecilia]]''<ref name=Lynch/> | |- | '''1783'''
| * 10 August (?) – Eliza gives birth to a daughter and develops [[postpartum depression]]<ref name=MandS/><ref name=CC/> * Wollstonecraft's second job – starts school in [[Islington]]<ref name=MandS/>
| | [[File:Montgolfier Balloon.JPG|right|100x100px|alt=Picture of a model of a hot air balloon, which has a blue background and is decorated with gold.]] * 3 September – [[Treaty of Paris (1783)|Treaty of Versailles]] signed, formally ending the American Revolution<ref name=Lynch/> * 21 November – The [[Montgolfier brothers]] of France launch the first manned hot-air balloon<ref name=Lynch/><ref>[http://www.allstar.fiu.edu/aero/balloon2.htm Balloons (1700–1900)]. ALLSTAR. Retrieved 6 August 2007.</ref> * December – [[William Pitt the Younger|William Pitt]] becomes [[Prime Minister of Great Britain]]<ref name=Norton/><ref name=BBC/> |- | '''1784'''
| [[File:Richard Price West.jpg|right|100x100px|alt=Quarter-length portrait of a man wearing minister's clothes and a wig.]] * At the instigation of Wollstonecraft, Eliza leaves her husband and child (who dies later in the year)<ref name=CC/> * Wollstonecraft's school moves from Islington to [[Newington Green]]; Eliza, Everina, and Fanny help teach<ref name=CC/> * Wollstonecraft becomes friends with the minister [[Richard Price]] (''pictured'')<ref name=CC/> * Wollstonecraft meets author [[Samuel Johnson]]<ref name=CC/> | | * [[Pitt's India Act]] gives the British Crown the power to guide Indian politics (as opposed to officers of the [[Honourable East India Company|East India Company]])<ref name=RC/> |- | '''1785'''
| * February – Fanny Blood marries Hugh Skeys in [[Lisbon]]<ref name=MandS/> * Wollstonecraft travels to Lisbon<ref name=MandS/> * November – Fanny gives birth to a child and dies shortly thereafter<ref name=MandS/> * December – Wollstonecraft returns to London<ref name=MandS/>
| * Publication of [[William Cowper]]'s poem ''[[The Task (poem)|The Task]]''<ref name=Norton/> | |- | '''1786'''
| * Wollstonecraft's school in [[Newington Green]] fails due to financial difficulties<ref name=CC/> * August – Wollstonecraft's third job – [[governess]] to the [[Anglo-Irish]] Kingsborough family<ref name=MandS/><ref>Todd, 79.</ref> * Wollstonecraft begins work on her [[conduct book]], ''[[Thoughts on the Education of Daughters]]''<ref name=CC/> | | * December – [[Shays' Rebellion]] (December 1786 – January 1787)<ref name=Lynch/> * Beginning of [[Impeachment of Warren Hastings|impeachment proceedings]] against [[Warren Hastings]], Governor-General of India<ref name=RC/> |- | '''1787''' | [[File:WollstonecraftEducation.png|right|100x100px|alt=Page reads "THOUGHTS ON THE EDUCATION OF DAUGHTERS. THE NURSERY. As I conceive it to be the duty of every rational creature to attend to its offspring, I am sorry to observe, that reason and duty together have not so powerful an influence over human"]] * Publication of Wollstonecraft's first book, ''[[Thoughts on the Education of Daughters]]'' (''pictured'') by [[Joseph Johnson (publisher)|Joseph Johnson]]<ref name=MandS/> * Wollstonecraft travels with the Kingsboroughs to [[Bristol]] where she writes her first novel, ''[[Mary: A Fiction]]'', and the fragment "Cave of Fancy"<ref name=CC/> * August – Wollstonecraft is dismissed from her governess position by Lady Kingsborough<ref name=MandS/> * Wollstonecraft returns to London<ref name=MandS/> * Wollstonecraft's fourth job – translator, reader, reviewer, and editorial assistant for Joseph Johnson and [[Thomas Christie]]'s ''[[Analytical Review]]''<ref name=CC/> * Through Johnson, Wollstonecraft meets political reformer [[Thomas Holcroft]], artist and writer [[Henry Fuseli]], radical [[Joel Barlow]], linguist and reformer [[John Horne Tooke]], and writer [[Anna Laetitia Barbauld]]<ref name=CC/> | | * 13 May – [[History of Australia (1788-1850)|First fleet of convicts]] sails to penal colony in Australia from Britain<ref name=BBC/> * 22 May – [[Committee for the Abolition of the Slave Trade]] is formed in Britain<ref name=BBC/> |- | '''1788'''
| * May – ''[[Analytical Review]]'' begins publication<ref name=RC/> * Publication of Wollstonecraft's first novel, ''[[Mary: A Fiction]]'', by Johnson<ref name=MandS/> * Publication of Wollstonecraft's children's book, ''[[Original Stories from Real Life]]'', by Johnson<ref name=MandS/> * Publication of Wollstonecraft's translation of [[Jacques Necker]]'s ''Of the Importance of Religious Opinions'' by Johnson<ref name=MandS/> | * 1 January – First edition of ''[[The Times (London)|The Times]]'' of London is published<ref name=BBC/> * Publication of [[Charlotte Turner Smith|Charlotte Smith's]] novel ''[[Emmeline]]''<ref name=RC/> | * November – Beginning of the [[George IV of the United Kingdom#Regency|Regency Crisis]], caused by [[George III|George III's]] [[Porphyria|madness]]<ref name=BBC/> |- | '''1789''' | * Publication of Wollstonecraft's anthology, ''The Female Reader'', by Johnson (published under the pseudonym of Mr. Cresswick)<ref name=CC/> * Wollstonecraft becomes romantically involved with the artist and writer [[Henry Fuseli]]<ref name=Taylor/> | * 29 April – Publication of ''[[The Interesting Narrative of the Life of Olaudah Equiano]]'', an autobiography by a former slave * Publication of [[William Blake]]'s poems ''[[Songs of Innocence]]''<ref name=Kelly/> | [[File:Prise de la Bastille.jpg|right|100x100px|alt=On the left-hand side of the painting, a building with towers is being attacked and is bathed in flames. On the right-hand side, black smoke billows around. At the base of the piece, small people are fighting and destroying the building brick by brick.]] * 20 June – [[Tennis Court Oath]] taken by the [[National Assembly (French Revolution)|French National Assembly]]<ref name=RC/> * 14 July – [[Storming of the Bastille]] in Paris (''pictured'')<ref name=BBC/><ref name=CC/> * 26 August – The French Assembly adopts the [[Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen]]<ref name=Lynch/><ref>[http://avalon.law.yale.edu/18th_century/rightsof.asp Declaration of the Rights of Man]. Avalon Project at [[Yale Law School]]. Retrieved 14 April 2012.</ref> * 5–6 October – "[[The March on Versailles|October days]]"; Parisian women, unable to buy bread, march to Versailles and bring the royal family back to Paris<ref name=Lynch/> * 4 November – [[Richard Price]] gives his sermon "[[A Discourse on the Love of Our Country]]" at a meeting of the London Revolution Society, to which Burke would respond a year later, igniting the [[Revolution Controversy]] in Britain<ref name=Lynch/> * December – End of the [[George IV of the United Kingdom#Regency|Regency Crisis]] (George III recovers)<ref name=BBC/><ref name=Kelly>Kelly, Gary. "Chronology". ''English Fiction of the Romantic Period, 1789–1830''. London: Longman (1989).</ref> |}

{| class="wikitable" |-
!Year !width=31%|Wollstonecraft !width=31%|Literature !width=31%|History |- | '''1790''' | [[File:WollstonecraftVRM.jpg|right|100x100px|alt=Title page reads "A Vindication of the Rights of Men, in a Letter to the Right Honourable Edmund Burke; Occasioned by His Reflections on the Revolution in France. By Mary Wollstonecraft. The Second Edition. London: Printed for J. Johnson, No. 72, St. Paul's Church-Yard. M.DCC.XC."]] * Publication of Wollstonecraft's translation of Maria Geertruida van de Werken de Cambon's ''Young Grandison'' by Johnson<ref name=MandS/> * Publication of Wollstonecraft's translation of [[Christian Gotthilf Salzmann]]'s ''Elements of Morality, for the Use of Children'', illustrated by [[William Blake]], by Johnson<ref name=MandS/> * 29 November – Publication of the first edition Wollstonecraft's treatise ''[[A Vindication of the Rights of Men]]'' by Johnson (anonymous)<ref name=CC/> * 18 December – Publication of the second edition of ''[[A Vindication of the Rights of Men]]'', with Wollstonecraft's name on the title page, by Johnson (''pictured'')<ref name=CC/> * Wollstonecraft temporarily adopts Ann, a seven-year-old relative of Hugh Skeys (Fanny Blood's husband)<ref name=MandS/> | * 1 November – Publication of [[Edmund Burke]]'s treatise ''[[Reflections on the Revolution in France]]''<ref name=CC/> * Publication of [[Helen Maria Williams]]'s ''[[Letters from France]]''<ref name=Lynch/> | * Motions for the repeal of the [[Test Act|Test]] and [[Corporation Act 1661|Corporation Acts]] withdrawn<ref name=Kelly/> * Breach between [[Edmund Burke]] and [[Charles James Fox]] over the [[French Revolution]]<ref name=Kelly/> |- | '''1791''' | * 1 September – Publication of the second edition of Wollstonecraft's ''[[Original Stories from Real Life]]'', with illustrations by [[William Blake]], by Johnson<ref name=CC/><br/><ref name=Lynch/> * September – Wollstonecraft begins writing ''[[A Vindication of the Rights of Woman]]''<ref name=MandS/> * November – Wollstonecraft first meets [[William Godwin]] at one of [[Joseph Johnson (publisher)#Johnson Circle and dinners|Johnson's famous dinners]]; they dislike each other<ref name=CC/> * Wollstonecraft has her portrait painted by [[John Opie]] (see top of page)<ref>Todd, 155.</ref> | [[File:Thomas Paine.jpg|right|100x100px|alt=Half=length portrait of a man turned towards the left and looking inquiringly out towards the viewer. He is wearing a dark red velvet jacket and a white shirt and there are papers next to him.]] * February–March – Publication of Part I of [[Thomas Paine]]'s (''pictured'') pamphlet ''[[Rights of Man]]''<ref name=Lynch/><ref name=Kelly/> * Publication of [[Elizabeth Inchbald]]'s novel ''[[A Simple Story (novel)|A Simple Story]]''<ref name=Kelly/> * Publication of [[James Boswell]]'s ''[[Life of Johnson]]''<ref name=Kelly/> * Publication of [[Ann Radcliffe]]'s novel ''[[The Romance of the Forest]]''<ref name=Lynch/> * Publication of [[Erasmus Darwin]]'s poems ''[[The Botanic Garden]]''<ref name=RC/> * Publication of [[Charlotte Turner Smith|Smith's]] novel ''[[Celestina (novel)|Celestina]]''<ref name=RC/> | * 19 April – The [[British House of Commons|British parliament]] rejects [[William Wilberforce]]'s [[William Wilberforce#Abolition campaign|bill to abolish the slave trade]]<ref name=BBC/> * 14–17 July – [[Priestley Riots]]; rioting aimed at [[English dissenters|religious Dissenters]] in [[Birmingham]]<ref name=Kelly/> * August – 100,000 slaves and ex-slaves [[Haitian Revolution|revolt against planters and the local government]] in French-controlled [[San Domingo]], the wealthiest colony of the West Indies and main source of sugar and coffee in Europe<ref name=RC/> |- | '''1792''' | [[File:WollstonecraftVindicationWomanTitle.jpg|right|100x100px|alt=Title page reads "A Vindication of the Rights of Woman: with Strictures on Political and Moral Subjects. By Mary Wollstonecraft. London: Printed for J. Johnson, No. 72, St. Paul's church-Yard. 1792."]] * January – Publication of Wollstonecraft's treatise ''[[A Vindication of the Rights of Woman]]'' by Johnson<ref name=MandS/> * February – Wollstonecraft meets [[Talleyrand]], to whom she dedicated the ''Rights of Woman''<ref name=MandS/> * Wollstonecraft falls in love with [[Henry Fuseli]]<ref name=CC/> * Wollstonecraft, Fuseli, and his wife come to an emotional crisis<ref name=MandS/> * December – Wollstonecraft leaves for Paris<ref name=MandS/> * Wollstonecraft meets revolutionary [[Thomas Paine]] and writer [[Helen Maria Williams]] in Paris<ref name=CC/> * Commissioned by friend and artist [[William Roscoe]], Wollstonecraft's portrait is painted by an unknown artist<ref name=CC/><ref>Todd, 266a.</ref> | * Publication of [[Robert Bage (novelist)|Robert Bage's]] novel ''[[Man As He Is]]''<ref name=Kelly/> * Publication of [[Hannah More]]'s pamphlet ''[[Village Politics]]''<ref name=Kelly/> * Publication of [[Charlotte Turner Smith|Smith's]] novel ''[[Desmond (novel)|Desmond]]''<ref name=RC/> | * 25 January – The [[London Corresponding Society]] (1792 – 1794) formed under the leadership of [[Thomas Hardy (political reformer)|Thomas Hardy]]<ref name=Lynch/><ref name=BBC/><ref name=Kelly/> * 7 March – [[Sierra Leone]] is established under British rule as a home for former slaves<ref name=BBC/> * 10 August – [[10 August (French Revolution)|Attack on the Tuileries Palace]] leads to the [[The Legislative Assembly and the fall of the French monarchy|deposition of Louis XVI]] and the dissolution of the Legislative Assembly<ref name=Lynch/> * 2–6 September – "[[September Massacres]]"; 12,000 political prisoners murdered in France<ref name=RC/> * 21 September – Newly elected [[National Convention|National Convention abolishes the monarchy]] and officially declares France a Republic<ref name=Lynch/> * 20 November – [[John Reeves (activist)|John Reeves]] founds the [[Association for Preserving Liberty and Property against Republicans and Levellers]] in Britain in response to the French Revolution and the London Corresponding Society<ref name=RC/> * 18 December – [[Thomas Paine|Paine]] is found guilty of [[seditious libel]] for the ''[[Rights of Man]]'' and sentenced to death in Britain<ref name=Lynch/> |- | '''1793''' | * Wollstonecraft meets and falls in love with American adventurer [[Gilbert Imlay]] in France<ref name=MandS/> * Wollstonecraft registers as Imlay's wife at the United States embassy in France for protection during the [[Reign of Terror]]<ref name=MandS/> * June – Wollstonecraft moves from Paris to [[Neuilly]]<!--I have to figure out which one--> to escape the revolutionary violence<ref name=CC/> * September – Wollstonecraft, now pregnant, returns to Paris<ref name=CC/> | * 14 February – Publication of [[William Godwin|Godwin's]] treatise ''[[Political Justice]]''<ref name=Lynch/><ref name=Kelly/> * Publication of [[Charlotte Turner Smith|Smith's]] novel ''[[The Old Manor House]]''<ref name=RC/> | [[File:Élisabeth Vigée Le Brun - Marie-Antoinette au livre - 1785.jpg|right|100x100px|alt=Three-quarter length portrait of a woman holding a book on a green velvet pillow. She is wearing a red and gold velvet dress adorned with a thin, white organza around the bosom and a gray wig, also adorned by thin, white material.]] * 21 January – Execution of [[Louis XVI]]<ref name=CC/> * 1 February – France [[French Revolutionary Wars#War of the First Coalition|declares war]] on England<ref name=CC/> * 11 March – Civil war erupts in France with the [[revolt in the Vendée]]<ref name=RC/> * July – Beginning of the [[Reign of Terror]] in France<ref name=Lynch/> * 16 October – Execution of [[Marie Antoinette]] (''pictured'')<ref name=CC/> |- | '''1794''' | * January – Wollstonecraft moves to [[Le Havre, France]]<ref name=CC/> * 14 May – Birth of Wollstonecraft and Imlay's daughter, [[Fanny Imlay]], in Le Havre<ref name=MandS/> * [[Gilbert Imlay|Imlay]] returns to England, leaving Wollstonecraft and their daughter alone<ref name=CC/> * December – Publication of Wollstonecraft's ''An Historical and Moral View of the Origin and Progress of the French Revolution'' in London<ref name=CC/> | * 28 May – Publication of [[William Godwin|Godwin's]] novel ''[[Caleb Williams]]''<ref name=Lynch/><ref name=Kelly/> * Publication of [[William Blake|Blake's]] poems ''[[Songs of Experience]]''<ref name=Kelly/> * Publication of [[Thomas Paine|Paine's]] treatise ''[[The Age of Reason]]''<ref name=Kelly/> * Publication of [[Ann Radcliffe|Radcliffe's]] novel ''[[The Mysteries of Udolpho]]''<ref name=Lynch/> | * 4 February – France [[Abolitionism#France|abolishes slavery]] in its colonies<ref name=RC/> * 7 May – ''[[Habeas corpus]]'' is suspended in Britain<ref name=Lynch/> * Late July – [[Robespierre]] is executed and the Reign of Terror ends<ref name=Lynch/><ref name=CC/> * November – British radicals are acquitted at the [[1794 Treason Trials]]<ref name=Lynch/><ref name=Kelly/> |- | '''1795'''
| * April – Wollstonecraft returns to London to join Imlay and learns of his infidelity<ref name=CC/> * May – Wollstonecraft's first suicide attempt; she is saved by Imlay<ref name=CC/> * June–September – Wollstonecraft journeys to Scandinavia on business for Imlay<ref name=MandS/> * October – Wollstonecraft's second suicide attempt; she jumps off Putney Bridge into the [[River Thames]] and is saved by strangers<ref name=CC/> | [[File:HannahMore.jpg|right|100x100px|alt=Oil painting of a woman sitting in a striped chair. She is wearing a dark-colored dress, with a shawl, contrasted with her tight, white cap and collar. Next to her is a table with writing instruments.]] * [[Hannah More]] begins publishing the ''[[Cheap Repository Tracts]]'' to counteract radical publications<ref name=RC/> | * 29 October – On the way to parliament, [[George III]] is attacked by a hungry mob<ref name=Lynch/> * 18 December – [[Seditious Meetings Act 1795|Seditious Meetings Act]] and [[Treasonable Practices Act]] passed (also known as the "Two Acts" or the "Gagging Acts")<ref name=Lynch/><ref name=Kelly/> * [[Methodist Church of Great Britain|Methodist]]s secede from the [[Church of England]]<ref name=Kelly/> * The Famine Year<ref name=Lynch/><ref name=RC/> |- | '''1796'''
| * January – Publication of Wollstonecraft's ''[[Letters Written in Sweden, Norway, and Denmark]]'' by Johnson<ref name=MandS/> * 21 August – Wollstonecraft begins affair with [[William Godwin]]<ref name=MandS/><ref name=Lynch/> * Wollstonecraft starts to write ''[[Maria: or, The Wrongs of Woman]]''<ref name=CC/>
| * Publication of [[Robert Bage (novelist)|Bage's]] novel ''[[Hermsprong or Man as he is not|Hermsprong]]''<ref name=Kelly/> * Publication of [[Mary Hays]]'s novel ''[[Memoirs of Emma Courtney]]''<ref name=Kelly/> * Publication of Barbauld and Aikin's children's series ''[[Evenings at Home]]''<ref name=Lynch/> * Publication of [[Frances Burney|Burney's]] novel ''[[Camilla (Burney novel)|Camilla]]''<ref name=Lynch/> * Publication of [[Matthew Lewis (novelist)|Matthew Lewis's]] novel ''[[The Monk]]''<ref name=RC/> | * December – Failed [[French Revolutionary Wars: Campaigns of 1796|French landing]] at [[Bantry Bay]], West Cork, Ireland<ref name=Kelly/> * Failure of [[French Revolutionary Wars: Campaigns of 1796|peace negotiations]] between Britain and France<ref name=Kelly/> |- | '''1797'''
| [[File:Mary Wollstonecraft by John Opie (c. 1797).jpg|right|100x100px|alt=Left-looking portrait of a slightly pregnant woman in a white dress]] * [[John Opie]] paints Wollstonecraft's portrait (''at right'')<ref name=CC/> * 29 March – Wollstonecraft and Godwin marry; they lose friends because it is revealed that Wollstonecraft was never married to Imlay<ref name=CC/> * 30 August – Birth of Wollstonecraft and Godwin's daughter, [[Mary Shelley]], future author of ''[[Frankenstein]]''<ref name=MandS/> * 10 September – Death of Mary Wollstonecraft from complications in childbirth<ref name=MandS/> | * 20 November – Publication of the first issue of the ministerial journal, the ''[[Anti-Jacobin Review]]''<ref name=Lynch/> * Publication of [[William Godwin|Godwin's]] ''[[The Enquirer (Godwin)|The Enquirer]]''<ref name=Kelly/> * Publication of Radcliffe's novel ''[[The Italian (novel)|The Italian]]''<ref name=Lynch/> | * February – [[Bank of England]] suspends cash payments<ref name=RC/> * April–June – [[Spithead and Nore mutinies|Naval mutinies]] occur at [[Spithead]] and the [[Nore]]<ref name=BBC/> * Failure of [[French Revolutionary Wars: Campaigns of 1797|French landing]] in Wales<ref name=Kelly/> |- | '''1798'''
|[[File:WilliamGodwin.jpg|right|100x100px|alt=Half-length profile portrait of a man. His dark clothing blends into the background and his white face is in stark contrast.]] * Publication of ''Posthumous Works of the Author of a Vindication of the Rights of Woman'', edited by [[William Godwin|Godwin]] (''pictured'')<ref name=MandS/> * Publication of Godwin's ''[[Memoirs of the Author of A Vindication of the Rights of Woman]]'', the first biography of Wollstonecraft; Godwin's openness regarding her love affairs destroyed her reputation for a century<ref name=CC/> | * June – Publication of [[Thomas Robert Malthus]]'s ''[[An Essay on the Principle of Population]]''<ref name=Lynch/> * Publication of [[William Wordsworth]] and [[Samuel Taylor Coleridge]]'s poems ''[[Lyrical Ballads]]''<ref name=Kelly/> * Publication of [[Richard Lovell Edgeworth|Richard Lovell]] and [[Maria Edgeworth]]'s treatise ''[[Practical Education]]''<ref name=Lynch/> * Publication of [[Charlotte Turner Smith|Smith's]] novel ''[[The Young Philosopher]]''<ref name=RC/> | * 26 May – [[Society of United Irishmen]] rebel against British rule in Ireland<ref name=BBC/> * August–September – [[French Revolutionary Wars: Campaigns of 1798|French landing in Ireland]]<ref name=Kelly/> * 1 August – [[Horatio Nelson]]'s victory at the [[Battle of the Nile]]<ref name=Kelly/><ref>"French revolutionary and Napoleonic wars". [[Encyclopædia Britannica Online]]. Retrieved 6 August 2007.</ref> * [[Joseph Johnson (publisher)|Joseph Johnson]] and [[Gilbert Wakefield]] are imprisoned for [[seditious libel]]<ref name=Lynch/> |}

[[File:Triton fountain Valletta.jpg|thumb|The [[Triton Fountain (Malta)|Triton Fountain]] in [[Valletta]], which was designed by Anastasi together with the sculptor [[Vincent Apap]]]]
'''Victor Anastasi''' (1913–1992) was a [[Maltese people|Maltese]] designer. He worked as a draughtsman with the Public Works Department, and although he never formally studied architecture, he was involved in the design process of numerous buildings. He was an admirer of [[Italian architecture]], and often traveled to Rome where he often met with Maltese artists who were studying there.<ref name="1900–1970"/>
His most famous work is the [[Triton Fountain (Malta)|Triton Fountain]] in [[Valletta]], which he designed along with the sculptor [[Vincent Apap]] in the 1950s. Anastasi designed the architectural and technical elements of the fountain,<ref>{{cite news|title=Tritons’ Fountain, City Gate|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20120616/environment/Tritons-Fountain-City-Gate.424467|work=[[Times of Malta]]|date=16 June 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170417153059/http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20120616/environment/Tritons-Fountain-City-Gate.424467|archivedate=17 April 2017}}</ref> while Apap worked on the sculpture of the three bronze [[Triton (mythology)|Tritons]]. Anastasi was not mentioned on the fountain's proposal since PWD employees were ineligible in the competition.<ref name="1900–1970"/>
He also designed the Malta College of Arts, Science and Technology (now the [[Ġ. F. Abela Junior College]]) in [[Msida]], which was designed and built between 1962 and 1966.<ref name="1900–1970">{{cite book|last1=Muscat|first1=Mark Geoffrey|title=Maltese Architecture 1900–1970: Progress and Innovations|date=2016|publisher=Fondazzjoni Patrimonju Malti|location=[[Valletta]]|isbn=9789990932065|pages=100–102|chapter=Post-War Manifestations}}</ref>
